title: AT 1: Shopping
content:
Woke up early, got a long breakfast at the hotel.
Walked to the REI to get a bear can, gas, and various smaller things. After that: Grocery shopping at Walmart. A lot of things there I’ve never seen before; walked up and down the aisles for a very long time looking for suitable looking food. Will result in interesting meals…
Current part of town is nicely walkable, although hardly anyone is out there on foot. Booked an Uber to Amicalola tomorrow.
Ate good German style supper in bed.
Rest of the day was used for packing all up. Pack is quite heavy, I’ll have to shave off some weight in the next weeks for sure.

title: AT 64: 800 Miles Buena Vista
content:
Got a nice pancake breakfast at Stanimals, then headed back out to the trail.
Completed 800 miles, packed out junk/town food and had a good time. Hiked with Hello and Buckeye Boy for the day.
Got picked up in the evening by FREEDOM, who let Turmeric shuttle us into Buena Vista.
Stayed at the town pavilion, where we set up on the floor between the benches. Very nice setup, with showers and restrooms available for hikers. Got even a free ice cream at the local ice cream shop (strawberry).

title: AT 150: Baldplates
content:
Did a nice little slackpack of 10 miles today. Started out foggy and with a little sprinkling, then cleared up once over the Baldplate Peaks.
Great views from above. Fall vibes in the forest are starting now, with fallen leaves on the ground and that distinct fall smell in the air.
Returned to the hostel, where we moved from the couch to the trailer. It’s nice on the inside, and cooler than the bunk room, so that’s a win.
Got burgers for dinner, signed the dining room table, then off to bed.

title: AT 24: Smokies In The Rear View Mirror
content:
Got homemade breakfast, another shower for good measure and took our time before leaving Standing Bear. Fresh clothes and resupply should last to Hot Springs easily.
Due to the closure of Max Patch the mileages will be a little wonky the next few days. Cambio/Darth left their electronics bag behind at the cabin, so we’ll have to get that to Hot Springs before they leave town.
Did seven miles to Groundhog Creek Shelter, which is one of the smaller ones. Good water access, nice looking privy. They even got a bear box, very refreshing after the Smokies. Met Mississippi again at the shelter, which was a nice surprise.
On the way: Views of the Smokies from Snowbird Peak, flowers, AT-signs in cut logs.

title: AT 98: Slackpacking With Prepper
content:
We decided to slackpack some easy miles with Prepper, who is recovering from some health problems and is taking it slower.
Lot’s of big rocks, boulders, and using hands for scrambling. Nice to do it without a pack.
Ended up going to the neighbouring restaurant, which was really good. Airquotes, Iceman, Foxtrot were there as well. Got me some deep fried Cordon Bleu and Orange Chocolate Ice Cream.

title: AT 27: Laughing Heart Hostel
content:
Another zero day at another nice hostel. Thunderstorm in the morning, was very cozy being able to staying in bed.
Got breakfast with Cambio and his dad at the diner we got dinner the night before. They went on their way, we went on to do some shopping, relaxing, and eating.
Put up my tent on the hostel lawn again to dry it out. Did that yesterday as well, but took it down so late, that dew had already came down on it.
Did another run into town to resupply for the next five days. May have been overly cautious, food supply is exceeding maximum storage capacity slightly. Might have to slackpack tomorrow to make some miles.
Pancakes in the evening.

title: AT 114: Connecticut
content:
After looking at the shelter/camp site situation for the next few days, we opted for a short 12 mile day to sync up with the daily mileage/shelter plans we like to follow.
Crossed into Connecticut early in the day, and arrived at camp in the early afternoon.
Not many people there; we set up tent there to get away from the mosquitoes, which are becoming unbearable right now.

title: AT 0: Approach Trail
content:
Checked out from the hotel and took an Uber to Amicalola. Both hotel stay and Uber ride have been really nice.
At Amicalola I got the how-to-hike-the-AT lesson from the park ranger, my hang tag, the pic beneath the arch, and then was on my way.
The falls are spectacular, the steps not as bad as advertised. The rest of the trail is quite taxing though. Weather was hot.
Got to Springer Mountain at around 15:00 for more pics at the official southern terminus. Views are really good. Decided to camp at the shelter right there.
Met some nice ladies there who supplied me with S’mores, then went back up to Springer for sunset views.
Plan for tomorrow: Short day to Hawk Mountain Shelter. Could be raining, so a place in the shelter would be really nice.

title: Yosemite 4: Down The Canyon Part 2:
content:
Another day of following the river, ever deeper into the canyon. Wider and narrower parts, rocky trail (and another rattlesnake), Sequoia growths (lots of flies there).
Down at Pate Valley, at the end of the accessable part of the canyon, there are a lot of flat, nice tent sites, and we set up camp there for the night. A few other hikers down here, most of them having climbed down the canyon wall this morning.
That’s what will be our route tomorrow, but going up the wall, back to where we left our car. Not a long day mileage wise, but it will be all uphill, up the canyon wall, with not a lot of tree cover, and no reliable water sources. We decided to start tomorrow’s hike early, and were happy to be in camp by 5 PM (even with unsuccessfully scouting for campsites closer to the final climb, and a bit of backtracking).
In the evening the ranger, who had issued us our permit four days ago, checked in on us at our camp site, being on backcountry duty now. Funny to meet a known face in the middle of nowhere.

title: AT 87: 10 Before 12:
content:
Got up very early to beat the heat. Got our first 10 miles before noon. Very exciting! To celebrate that, we did just three miles more and stayed at the Thru It All Ministries. Had a new tent there waiting for us; gonna join the Dyneema gang!
Before getting there, we got some smoked meat sandwiches from a local BBQ joint.
Did a Walmart resupply, where we got fleece blankets for the summer. Let’s see if the $3 throw blanket works out…
Dinner at Dairy Queen, then we reorganized packs and shipped our tents and sleeping bags to Utah for the summer.
Bunks were all occupied, so we slept in the church’s children’s room.

title: AT 135: Slowly Out Of Hanover
content:
Got up and got some nice breakfast from Wren. Managed to stay until about noon, then back on trail and into town.
It’s new shoe day today! The old ones had 729 trail miles on them (and a few tens of non trail miles as well). Hope the new ones will last to the end.
Did resupply at CVS and co-op, where we met Foxtrot and Iroh. Went on and scoped out Buckeyes setup, who had put up tent in the woods behind the Dartmouth sportsball fields.
Hiked 11 easy miles to Moose Mountain Shelter, which is packed full for a change. Tomorrow will be a day with a lot of elevation change, so we went to bed early.

title: AT 92: Duncannon 2: Post Office Shenanigans
content:
Turns out, the package had never been delivered to the outfitter. There go our plans of hiking out of town at 10, or even today.
After a lot of waiting and a final visit at the post office we got the package finally and headed back to the church.
After removing, rebending, reinserting the stays of Turmerics backpack we decided it was too late to hike out and would stay for another night. Hopefully the pack will be fixed and doesn’t have to be replaced.
Washed my clothes in the shower in preparation for a longer stretch without a hostel stay.
The plan for tomorrow is to get up before 6 AM and hike out early.

title: AT 121: Urgent Care
content:
Decided to go check out Turmeric’s foot today. Shuttled into town with the hostel, got breakfast, picked up Turmeric’s resupply boxes and both our sleeping bags from the post office.
Buckeye drove us from there to the next in-network Urgent Care, which was a forty minute drive. Turned out better than expected; the doc told Turmeric that while it may hurt, it is not broken, but a contusion; and she can basically hike on it. Should get a treatment of RICE though.
Picked up some Ibuprofen and resupply on our way back, then stayed the rest of the day at the hostel icing the foot, and reorganizing the resupply boxes.
In the evening went out on a quick grocery run to a local creamery, which had delicious ice cream.

title: AT 139: Kinsmen
content:
Did South and North Kinsman today as an ‘easy’ 16 mile slackpack.
Started at 6:50 at Kinsman Notch in the fog. Weather cleared up while doing the Mt Wolf PUDs. Got our feet wet on the bog boards.
After that, hiked/scrambled up South Kinsman. Very windy on top, nice views. Then on to North Kinsman, where from a rocky ledge there are amazing views of Franconia Ridge. That’s what we’ll be walking over on Thursday.
Quick downhill dash to Lonesome Lake Hut, where we got soup together with Blue Pear and Tumbleweed. Then down the hill to our pickup point, and to the Notch Hostel.
Got a place to sleep in the shed, where we got a really good nights sleep; with the shed doors cracked open and cool air coming in it almost feels like home (a shelter).

title: AT 50: Town Food Right On Trail
content:
Lost Torch today, he didn’t make it to camp last night and didn’t catch up today.
Quick miles to Brushy Mountain Outpost, a diner right on trail. Made for good motivation. Got a bacon cheeseburger, chocolate/mint ice cream, soft drinks. Stayed there for like 2 hours.
After that more easy ridgeline walking to Jenny Knob Shelter. Passed the 600 mile marker. Got there early and were able to wash up in the stream. Met Toto and gang there again. Mimi, Sixpack, and Pigtails there as well.
Country Roads handed out trail magic in the form of self made bracelets.

title: AT 28: Slackpacking Trail Running Cookie Ladies
content:
Decided to slackpack the first few miles today, and started by going again through Hot Springs. Robin did buy short shorts at the outfitter as well, so all four of us are showing off the quads now.
Got our first sight of French Broad River, which we followed for a short time before the trail took us into the mountains again.
Mountain Laurel is starting to bloom right now, which is quite spectacular.
Hiking with a daypack feels like gliding up the hills. If not for the logistics involved, slackpacking could be a really addictive thing. Did some extra miles to Rich Mountain Fire Tower, which is really neatly built. After a last minute schedule change we had to resort to some three or four miles of trail running to get to our backpack shuttle in time.
Due to bear activity the last nine miles of the trail we’ve hiked so far have been shut down for tenting/staying the night since today.
Afterwards a short hike with now unreasonably heavy packs to Cookie Ladies’, who has a cabin right in the forest off the AT. Neatest cabin I’ve ever seen. Nobody there, but cookies were there in a box, and clean water, wet wipes, and a trash can as well. Thanks Cookie Lady! Saw a hummingbird from Cookie Ladies porch.
Then another three miles up the mountain to Little Laurel Shelter, where we were just able to squeeze into the shelter. Quick dinner, then bedtime.
Even with slackpacking this has been a long day, with just shy of twenty miles of hiking. Tomorrow probably a shorter day.

title: AT 104: Nyc Cobmin Ridge Left Wing 2:
content:
Turmeric’s parents have to fly back to Utah, so we went with them to Newark Airport, where they checked in, parked the car, then took the train into NYC.
Walked around a bit, got some food (expensive, very good), walked around a bit more. Turmeric’s parents left early to catch their flight, then it started pouring rain. Got into McD’s to wait it out (expensive, mediocre), then went to Central Park.
Got some big NY boulders there, on which I promptly slipped and fell. Bruised my leg and shattered my camera screen. Not impressed with NYC.
After a little more walking we took the train back to Newark, got the car, and headed back to the hostel.

title: AT 153: Slog Slog Slog
content:
A wet and muddy hike today. Started out quite foggy, then cleared up a bit. On and off drizzle all day. Terrain was mostly flat, very rooty and muddy though, which made for slow progress.
Checked into the Hiker Hut in the evening, where the next resupply package was waiting. Got an old camper as accommodation again. Nice property by a creek with an outdoor shower, completely off grid.

title: AT 51: Waterfall Bathing Woods Hole
content:
Started late from Jenny Knob Shelter; first goal of the day was Dismal Falls about 6.5 miles out. Day/hiking felt sluggish. Probably the heat/humidity.
The falls were great; went for a quick dip in the pool below the falls. Quite cold, exquisitely refreshing. Washed the salt out of the hiking clothes and relaxed a bit on the rocks. Weather was perfect for this kind of thing.
Mimi appeared at the falls with a bottle of cocktail mix celebrating her birthday.
Afterwards another 15 miles, first along the Dismal Creek (muddy), then up on the ridgeline (rocky). Turmeric and I decided to go for Woods Hole Hostel, elegantly bridging a dry stretch up on the ridge. Got good views up there and some great light from the setting sun. Buckeye Boy opted for carrying water up to the ridge and camping there.
Woods Hole is really nice. Got a salad, bread, and cheese despite coming in late. Additionally ate my own PB/cheese tortillas and some of Turmerics Alfredo as well. Bunk room feels really cozy. Relaxed atmosphere all around.
content_html:
Started late from Jenny Knob Shelter; first goal of the day was Dismal Falls about 6.5 miles out. Day/hiking felt sluggish. Probably the heat/humidity.

The falls were great; went for a quick dip in the pool below the falls. Quite cold, exquisitely refreshing. Washed the salt out of the hiking clothes and relaxed a bit on the rocks. Weather was perfect for this kind of thing.

Mimi appeared at the falls with a bottle of cocktail mix celebrating her birthday.

Afterwards another 15 miles, first along the Dismal Creek (muddy), then up on the ridgeline (rocky). Turmeric and I decided to go for Woods Hole Hostel, elegantly bridging a dry stretch up on the ridge. Got good views up there and some great light from the setting sun. Buckeye Boy opted for carrying water up to the ridge and camping there.

Woods Hole is really nice. Got a salad, bread, and cheese despite coming in late. Additionally ate my own PB/cheese tortillas and some of Turmerics Alfredo as well. Bunk room feels really cozy. Relaxed atmosphere all around.

title: AT 5: Birds Of A Feather
content:
After a convenient hostel stay and some gear resupply at the amazing outfitter at Mountain Crossings we were on our way. The mornings are bitterly cold, but the clear weather soon gets the temperature to rise.
Spent the day with Robin and Tim, the other two Germans on this part of the trail. Good company.
Encountered first proper Trail Magic in the form of camping chairs, a cooler with ice/softdrinks, snacks, and a trash bag. Spirits were lifted (not that it would’ve been needed, but we didn’t complain).
Staying at Low Gap Shelter tonight (tenting); many familiar faces here tonight. There are no bear boxes, so had to stash bear can in the forest for the first time.

title: AT 112: State Park Hot Dogs
content:
Decided to stay another night in the park, so we left our tent up and standing, while heading out on trail again.
Had second breakfast at the local lake shore food facility (egg sandwiches in a pretzel bun) about two miles into the day.
Lunch at a incredibly well kempt tent site, that didn’t seem to see much traffic.
Lot’s of water caches around here. The locals seem not to be convinced that the streams here are potable.
In the evening Buckeye picked us up again, went to a gas station for beer and hot dogs, which we grilled over a campfire back at the state park.

title: AT 88: Halfway There
content:
Got up early at Thru It All, got out of the children’s room, got breakfast (scones and eggs/ham/mushrooms).
Started the hike with a 0.8 mile roadwalk back to the trail, then onwards.
Met a rattlesnake, got rattled at, went on. At noon, a thunderstorm. Waited that out on the porch of a hut, then went on in the rain.
Arrived at the halfway point lately in the afternoon. Only 1099.2 miles left!
Met some dayhikers at a shelter, who gave us watermelon. Found a water cache up on the ridge as well.
Weather got better in the evening. Arrived at Pine Grove Furnace just before 7. Met up with Nightowl and Woodchuck, who were meeting up with Turmeric for some scheduled trail magic.
Checked into the Ironmasters Mansion for the night, which is an historic building on the furnace complex converted into a hostel.

title: AT 7: The Hostel Around The Bend
content:
A chill hike on the map, which doesn’t show all the rocks and roots on the trail. Wasn’t so chill on the hills. The Georgia sun sure has some heft to it.
Came down another steep hill to the Hostel Around The Bend, which is a big step up from the Neel Gap hostel. May be the best hostel in existence.
Washed clothes, got loaner clothes, and a shuttle into Hiawassee for resupply and fast food. Got 1300 calories at Zaxby’s, which I didn’t even know before.
Bought a stylish new bum bag and a replacement dry bag at the on site outfitter.

title: AT 32: Erwin Tn
content:
No bear activity at the shelter, but snake sighting. Keeps the mice in check, so thats perfectly fine.
Just about six miles down to Erwin. Really good views of the Nolichucky River from up above. Everytime you come down into the valleys the change of weather, humidity comes as a slight shock.
Hostel is right on trail; took the shuttle into town, resupplied and ate dinner at the supermarket deli. Chicken tenders, macaroni salad, a whole jar of Talenti (just for future cold soaking meals, of course). Got some free cake from people at the store. Fat and happy back to the hostel.
Tomorrow big plans again: trying to slackpack twenty miles. Gotta get as close to Damascus/trail days as possible until next weekend.

title: AT 158: Bigelows
content:
Got dropped off at the trailhead by Jen, got trail magic there, then off to tackle the last big mountains.
Beautiful weather, good views again, and nicely graded and maintained trail.
When we got our packs handed to us at the end of the day by Jen, the trail magic people were camped out at the spot. Decided to set up camp right there.
Beautiful sky out there, saw shooting stars. Rain is forecasted for the night, but until we went to sleep, we had clear skies.

title: Yosemite 0: Off To California
content:
Doing backcountry backpacking in Yosemite comes with challenges. The first one we got out of the way way back in the beginning of March: Permits! We applied for a few of the good looking trailheads, and after a round of no luck, got a permit for White Wolf Trailhead. This would allow us to start there, and then to roam the park for basically as long as the food on our backs would last.
Mapped out a loop starting at White Wolf, going to Ten Lakes, McGee Lake, then down the Tuolumne River to Pate Valley, then back up to White Wolf. Will be 48 miles of backcountry stuff over 5ish days.
Having taken care of administrative stuff and traveled to SLC, things are about to get serious.
For a few days now we’ve been getting our stuff together, getting Turmeric a shiny new bear can (another park stipulation), and packing up an unreasonable amount of oatmeal (we prepared 70 ziplocks of fancy PB-choccy-oats shared between Turmeric and me).
So today we started the long drive over to California. Some 570 miles through mostly the Nevada desert. Starting going west over the salt flats, then entering Nevada and a new time zone. Many miles over empty highways, great views of the desert, National Forests, long stretches, going straight as an arrow, then winding roads over lonely mountain ranges.
With the waning sun we entered California and were greeted by great views of Mono Lake. Took advantage of BLM land just before the park junction and set up the big car camping tent for the night.
Next day we’d enter the park, and then the adventure will begin for real.

title: AT 151: Almost Zero Southern Maine
content:
Another short 10 mile slackpack over Wyman Mountain and Moody Mountain. Started at 9:00, finished at 3 PM. Serious rain started when we were finished, so got back to our trailer dry.
Had the afternoon for relaxing, then got Shepherds Pie from Honey.

Had the afternoon for relaxing, then got Shepherds Pie from Honey.

title: AT 119: Upper Goose Pond
content:
As the shelter has been really crowded this night, and just about everyone wanting to go to Goose Pond today, we wanted to get there early to get a bunk bed there.
After leaving the South Mt. Wilcox Shelters really early, we were ahead of most of the people there. Leapfrogged PBJ and Chumbawamba all day. Didn’t stop much all day, except for trail magic by one of the former owners of the Pond itself.
Made it to the Cabin by 4 PM, with plenty of bunks available. Got a canoe from Vlobster, the caretaker, and went out on the lake for a afternoon paddle. Buckeye Boy made it to the Cabin a few minutes later, hiking in from a local trailhead (brought McD!).
Had a nice evening, then early to bed.

title: AT 148: Maine
content:
Another long day. Fascinating how hard 14.5 miles can be. Did the 10 mile Gentian Pond to Full Goose run in about eight hours.
Nice views of incoming storms up top, bogs there as well.
Crossed into Maine today; the last state; walked from Georgia to Maine now!
Made it to the shelter without headlamps today, so that’s a win.

title: AT 4: Blood Mountain Mountain Crossings
content:
Rained all night long, then stopped just right for hiking out.
The climb up Blood Mountain was good hiking. There’s a neat stone shelter on top. Views could’ve been better. The climb down was treacherous, even without rain.
Did the four miles to Mountain Crossings with Bret and Mark, where we parted ways for now. Thanks again for your company!
Decided to give my foot some more rest and get warm food in my belly, and booked into the hostel at Mountain Crossings. Either American frozen pizzas are better than the ones at home or my standards went down considerably. First shower since Wednesday morning.
Amount of people in hostel: 9.
Amount of Germans in hostel: 3.
More: Shoes in trees, resupply for the next days.

title: AT 35: Roan Highland Balds
content:
Started the day by divvying up the remainders of the trail magic, then headed out into the cold.
Weather was primarily consisting of a cloud we walked in for the first hours. The first bald we crossed with zero visibility and horizontal rain/mist/fog.
Clouds started to come undone a little bit, which gave way to dramatic views of forest/hills/clouds.
Around noon the clouds were all but vanished and there were great views of and from Little Hump and Hump Mountain. Up there a longer rest, then grueling five miles down the hill.
Evening/night at The Station, a bar/hostel combo deal. Got good grub there and hopefully good breakfast tomorrow.

title: AT 136: Smarts Mountain
content:
Another big day planned. Over 5000 ft of elevation change and just shy of 18 miles. Got up early and hiked all day, as we do.
Terrain got noticeably rockier, climbs got steeper. Probably a small taste of the Whites. Made it up Smarts Mountain, climbed up the fire tower, had great views.
Then quite strenuous five miles to the Hexacuba Shelter, which is a six sided shelter, and has a five sided privy.

title: AT 62: Creek Bathing
content:
Another day walking besides the Blue Ridge Parkway.
Got trail magic oranges from random SOBO dayhikers.
Stopped for lunch at a creek, where we took an extended dip. Very refreshing.
Long stretch to next shelter. Chill evening with campfire. Hello, Airquotes, Grits there.
More: Saw an AWACS.

title: AT 75: Shenandoah Milkshakes
content:
Retired the first pair of hiking socks after 940 miles. Now I’m on the Darn Tough train like almost everybody else.
Hiked out late, slackpacking again.
Got into the last Wayside for the famous Blackberry Milkshake and a burger.

title: AT 38: Trail Days DAY 2:
content:
Back to Damascus for more Trail Days.
Dropped off my backpack at the Osprey repair booth to fix my ripped side pocket mesh and take in the hip belt, because it’s gotten a lot looser in the last weeks.
Started to work on the loose hipbelt problem from another angle: by stuffing our faces. Ate eight pancakes, a big burrito, ice cream, Goldbären, popcorn, chips with salsa, brownies, a bagel.
Went on to get a free haircut at the One Way Ministries. Got my repaired pack back at noon. Watched the thruhiker parade in the middle of town and got new shoes at the outfitter.
Then the premiere of a film Darwin and Jennifer Pharr Davis did together with Sawyer. Great documentary and great bunch of people.
Afterwards met up with Cambio and his dad at the town’s distillery. Great place, but limited the number of drinks to two. Strange rules. Got away with having three, then bought some bottles of wine at the Dollar General and went into Tent City with Torch, Turmeric, and Cambio. But not without checking into the One Way Church again and getting some food there first.
Tent City was a blast. Wild people, Big bonfires, roasted pigs, handmade percussion music. Was on the drums for about half an hour.
Warren Doyle picked us up afterwards and drove us back to his place. Very nice guy, and his place is really special.
Plan for tomorrow: Real zero day without activities. Much needed after these two days.

title: AT 29: Big Firescald Knob 300: Miles Big Butt
content:
Another hot day. Took a detour to Blackstack Cliffs, which had been recommended by Cambio. Views were fantastic, even a snake enjoyed them and the warm rocks.
Made our way over Big Firescald Knob, which was a quite exposed ridgeline walk over very rocky terrain. Passed the 300 mile marker just after the ridge.
After that, Big Butt with big cracks in big rocks. Flint Mountain Shelter was just two hours after the summit and the end of our day.
Washed up a little, ate dinner, and then off to bed.

title: AT 109: Off Ramp Adventures
content:
More NY hiking. Big rocks, slanted bridges. Almost walked by the opportunity to see the NYC skyline from trail. Had to tell another hiker (Straight Edge) to look up from the trail as well.
There is a reroute of the AT here, which avoids a highway crossing that can get very busy. We took the original route, and got a not so busy highway crossing and a nicely built trail in the closed down section.
Planned to end the hike at Bear Mountain State Park, which had had some severe weather problems in the last few days.
Didn’t realize that they closed down any and all access to the park. In the evening Buckeye could not get us at the state park parking lot, because the whole highway on/off ramp was closed down. Had to roadwalk a mile out of the park, over the closed offramp, where Buckeye finally picked us up at the side of the highway.
Went to the movie theater for the last time. The car has some issues right now and we have an appointment at a car shop in Warwick tomorrow, so the movie theater is again the most convenient place to stay. Watched Barbie for a third time, we didn’t even need the radio to exactly know what happened in the movie.

Watched Barbie for a third time, we didn’t even need the radio to exactly know what happened in the movie.
meta_description: More NY hiking. Big rocks, slanted bridges. Almost walked by the opportunity to see the NYC skyline from trail. Had to tell another hiker (Straight Edge) to look up from the trail as well. There is a reroute of the AT here, which avoids a highway crossing that can get very busy. We took the…

title: AT 126: Repacking Stuff
content:
Buckeye is feeling better, so we decided to leave the car at Pokey’s, who offered his garage for a few weeks.
Got all the resupply items out of the car, repackaged everything, and shipped it either ahead or back to Utah.
Got a late breakfast at 1:30 PM (large pancakes, Vermont Maple Syrup, omelet, potatoes, toast, hot chocolate) with Buckeye and Maggs.
Went back to the trailhead, where we said farewell to Buckeye. He will stash the car in the next few days, then shuttle north, and get slowly on trail again till we catch up.
Hiked 1.6 miles out of town, and stayed in the Melville Nauheim Shelter. Maggs, Psyop, and Andrea, a German Long Trail hiker there as well.

title: AT 90: Kansas
content:
The tent held up. Lots of headroom in there. The Walmart blanket was a little bit cold. Not a good idea to get a blanket just 1.5 m in length.
Got a pic of the resident shelter copperhead in its den. It didn’t like being a model; shouldn’t have set up den a foot besides the firepit then.
Flattest day so far on the AT. Got a little bit into civilization, a lot of farmland and finally views more than of the next few yards. Got that Midwest vibe.
Weather was hot enough to use the umbrellas for shade.
Walked into Boiling Springs. Really pretty town. Got new trekking pole tips at the outfitter, checked out the gas station grocery, then out of town again.
Hit up a roadside produce/ice cream stand for blueberries and chocolate ice cream. Turmeric called ULA to get her backpack repaired.
Set up tent at Darlington Shelter for the night.

title: AT 154: Off Grid Zero
content:
Took an unplanned zero to get some much needed rest. The Hiker Hut is really nice, and having no cell service and electricity may help relaxing.
Went into Rangeley to do laundry, charge up electronics, and resupply, then back to the trailer.

title: AT 93: Hiking Out Again
content:
Got up at 5:30 to get an early start and maybe beat the heat. Having booked a room at the Lookout Hostel in a few days and afterwards taking an unplanned zero has us on a tight schedule. Several big mile days needed to make it.
Got over the train tracks just before a long one came through. A lot of dry, rocky ridges today.
Got trail magic from Twizzler at noon (homemade banana bread, Twizzlers, Gatorade).
Turmeric got stung by wasps about four times today. Stopped by a creek in the evening where she cooled down her feet and wasp stings.
Then another three miles to the top of the next hill, where we camped in a pine grove. Started to rain as soon as we got into the tent. In the night got woken up by porcupines rustling about. Weren’t bothered at all by being shined on with a headlamp.

title: AT 66: The Priest
content:
Woke up with a sore throat. Medicated with gummies from Watermelon Man.
Today: A long descent, followed by a long ascent. Stopped by the Priest Shelter for lunch and a read of the confessions journal.
Trail magic in the form of freeze dried physalis in the valley. Hot weather, but hazy again.
Set up camp at Harpers Creek Shelter, which is packed with dayhikers due to the Juneteenth weekend.
Food supply is running very low. Will arrive in Waynesboro hungry for sure. Fireflies are out in force here.

title: AT 65: Thunderstorms
content:
Started at the Route 60 trailhead, where we got peaches from a cat lady searching for her lost 21st cat.
A long ascent up the mountain, then more chill terrain.
Got chased down the mountain by a thunderstorm at 2 PM, which we waited out huddling under an umbrella. Hail, lightning, pouring rain. Went as fast as it came in, so half an hour later we hiked on.
Sun came out, haze in the air is gone.
Ended the day pretty early at the Seely Woodworth Shelter and had a relaxed dinner.

title: AT 97: Reunited With Buckeye Boy
content:
Turmerics shoes are completely shot right now and won’t be suitable for another big day, so she arranged a shoe pickup/slackpack meeting early in the morning. The new shoes had arrived at a hostel about 23 miles out and the owner was able to bring us the box. Got out very early to meet up with Yardsale 3 miles into the day.
Picked up new shoes and dropped off our packs; met Prepper for the first time, who was in the car with Yardsale, being shuttled in the area.
Then about another 20 miles to the Lookout Hostel. Two minutes before arriving there we got info that Buckeye Boy will be shuttling there as well. He showed up some time later with two roadtrippers, who picked him up back at Cross Trails. Happiness all around.

title: Yosemite 6: Day Hiking Half Dome
content:
Another early morning start, but left the tent set up for a change. Walked out of the campground over to the Happy Isles/JMT trailhead (now that’s goals…), then up, up, up.
Passed waterfalls, followed the Merced River, and gained elevation all morning long.
Arrived at the sub dome, which we climbed quickly, and were at the base of the cables. Being up at the sub dome is already impressive, but then there’s quite a bit of vertical gain left going up all the way. Pictures of the cables don’t really do it justice. It’s wild how steep parts of that thing are. People should not be allowed to do this.
Having done this climb once already, Turmeric had the foresight to borrow some climbing gear (Thanks Christie and Steve!), so we clipped onto the cables and were able to go up there relatively stress free.
Got to the top, had views for days, had a nice little chat with an older guy on his tenth ascent, got pics and pics taken, then went down the cables again.
A long way back to the campsite, which took us almost all of the afternoon, then a quick shower and back to bed. A long, strenuous day, but surely a thing that deserves to be on anyone’s bucket list. Was great fun and an experience for sure!

title: AT 100: Big Dave Trip L
content:
Took a zero at the hostel today. Went to the grocery store, had healthy lunch, relaxed a bit.
Turmerics parents arrived at the Lookout late afternoon. Took them three days of road tripping, coming over all the way from Utah. Now that’s a support team with dedication!
Happiness all around, then off to dinner at the Mason Jar place.

title: AT 12: Franklin Nc
content:
Night wasn’t as cold as expected. Got up at six to get to the shuttle pickup point to Franklin in time.
Got into town, and stored our packs at the Outdoor 76 gear shop for the day. Resupplied at Dollar General/Ingles. Had lunch/beer at the Lazy Hiker Company.
Went back to the the trail via shuttle, and hiked some more to Siler Bald Shelter.
Pack is considerably more heavy after resupply. Will have to eat more to get the weight down. Hopefully this will get us to the Smokies in a few days time.

title: AT 26: Salamanders Hot Springs
content:
The tent held, the clothes didn’t dry overnight. Started the day with a wet outfit. That’s what I signed up for, but not too pleasant anyways. At least the rain stopped.
First half of the day was a bit gloomy and wet, which brought the salamanders out. Hiking was good, on pine needle trails, bushes starting to flower, above the clouds.
Came into Hot Springs at around noon and checked into the Laughing Heart Hostel. Sun came out, so we dried out the tents. Went to the local diner for lunch, did a mini resupply (milk, cereal for the day).
In the evening we met up with Cambio and his dad, Turmeric returned their electronics bag, had some beers and S’mores. In bed late, as tomorrow we’ll take a zero (again).

title: AT 113: Camping With Buckeye
content:
Planned an easy day to Wiley Shelter, where Buckeye would be able to get easily to so he’d be able to camp with us.
Left the State Park early, then made good pace to the shelter. Got candy from a biker guy, crossed a railroad at the AT station, got the last NY food cart meal at a road crossing.
Set up the tent on a wooden platform for the first time, which always is a little bit of a hassle. Buckeye parked the car 0.2 miles down the trail, so we got stuff out of the car and Buckeye set up tent on trail for the first time in ages.
Drank some celebratory beers with The Mayor and crew, then off to bed.

title: Yosemite 2: High Sierra
content:
Started the day hiking out of the Ten Lakes region, and making our way towards Cathedral Creek.
A long, exposed way down to the canyon floor, then up the creek for a while. Crossing the creek we had a quick break, filtering water, watching trout, and, by accident, catching a fish in our water bag (we let it out into the creek again).
After going up the canyon wall on the opposite side again, we had an afternoon of high elevation passes and snow fed creeks, just all around beautiful scenery.
In the evening we made our way to McGee Lake, where we set up camp for the night. No good tenting spots there, and the lake was kinda murky as well. Turmeric found a little spot up above the trail, where we were able to pitch the tent quite well, though. Big granite wall in the background there made for impressive views.
Have been walking between 8000 and 10000 ft for the whole day. Tomorrow we’ll enter the big canyon and will drop down significantly in elevation.

title: AT 23: Exit The Smokies
content:
Did a short day to Standing Bear Farm. Almost just descent today, coming down from the smokies. Did a short side trail to Mt Cammerer Lookout Tower for the views, which were well worth the extra miles.
Heat in the afternoon after getting down below 2000 ft. Lush greens and humidity again.
Met Mississippi Guy (for the 6th time probably), who met up with his support crew (his wife) and organized some trail magic. Fruit and cold, sugary drinks. Hikers know best what hikers need. Thanks guys!
Very nice accommodation. Sharing a cabin with Tim, Robin, Turmeric, Cambio and Darth. Ate a big pizza on arrival and then a big dinner right afterwards. Washed clothes, relaxed on the porch, sat around the campfire for the evening (without puffy!).
Happy to get out of the Smokies before the weather turns, enjoying the warm temperatures again.
More: Flowers, horsing around, bear scat.

title: AT 9: Snakes No Plains And Arriving In North Carolina
content:
Left the hostel for Dick’s Creek Gap via shuttle.
Lost our German mate Tim due to cellphone-related business (he’s gotta find it or buy a new one).
Did 11.8 miles to Muskrat Creek Shelter, crossed into NC, saw a big old rattlesnake right on trail. Weather is good right now, but is expected to get wetter/colder the next days.
More: Orchids, hostel cat/mouse, ramen with peanut butter.

title: AT 31: Big Bald Big Miles
content:
Left the hostel early after another shower (may be one of our earliest starts at 8:30). Made our way out from Sam’s Gap.
Had to make up the miles from yesterday, and we did. About 18 miles today. We are on a fixed schedule to Erwin, where we have to be at Sunday, which will be a short day into town.
Good views from Big Bald, not worse than Max Patch. Nice dogs up there as well.
A lot of people have seen bears today, so let’s see if our food survives the night.
No rain today, so the umbrella attachment system stays untested.

title: AT 140: Bad Weather Zero
content:
Took a zero at the Notch Hostel. The High Peaks Forecast had some really nasty things to say about today’s weather, so we decided not to go up to Franconia Ridge, which is really exposed.
Used the day to relax and do some light chores. Borrowed bikes and went into town. Bought food, got a pair of Darn Toughs exchanged and bought a second one at the outfitter, got some maple-raspberry ice cream.
Cooked up some burgers, got ketchup from Corndog, who got a burger in exchange.
Turmeric got her new backpack frame shuttled in, I rebooked my flight back to Germany so we have a few days more.

title: AT 123: Halfway Up Mount Greylock
content:
Turmeric’s foot did feel good in the morning, so we headed out on trail again. Packed our stuff and left the Zero Day Hostel with Buckeye.
Slackpacked the first eight miles into Cheshire, got rained on briefly, then Buckeye met us there. Pokey was there as well and got us sandwiches, fruit juice and Gatorade. Bought some ice cream there, then hiked out with Buckeye and Maggs halfway up Mount Greylock.
Stayed in the shelter there. A gaggle of kids on a group trip was there as well, entertaining the thru hikers.

title: AT 79: Into Harpers Ferry
content:
Finished the Rollercoaster. No love lost. Then on to Harper’s Ferry.
Left Virginia for the last time somewhere, and got into West Virginia.
Crossed the Shenandoah River, went to the ATC Visitor Center, which is way off trail and was closed of course. All our phones died around that time.
Slogged on into the old town, which was eerily dead. Got some crap food and good milkshakes.
Then hiked out another mile to the hostel we plan on double zeroing at. Crossed the Potomac and into Maryland with that.
content_html:
Finished the Rollercoaster. No love lost. Then on to Harper’s Ferry.

Left Virginia for the last time somewhere, and got into West Virginia.

Crossed the Shenandoah River, went to the ATC Visitor Center, which is way off trail and was closed of course. All our phones died around that time.

Slogged on into the old town, which was eerily dead. Got some crap food and good milkshakes.

Then hiked out another mile to the hostel we plan on double zeroing at. Crossed the Potomac and into Maryland with that.

title: AT 56: Audie Murphy
content:
Another one of the Virginia ridge walks. Two ridges today. The first one with great views for a change.
Between the ridges: Trail magic by Allan, who cooked hot dogs for hikers. Met Smokey Bear again (after Warrens), who is supporting the mom with 13 kids on trail. Also met Bubbles and Mississippi, who we haven’t seen in a long time.
The second ridge walk was quite pretty, with grassy trail, blooming mountain laurel. Checked out the Audie Murphy memorial.
After coming down from the mountain we decided to camp at Trout Creek. Jason and a buddy were hanging out at the bridge and handing out beers. Nice evening. Jason told stories about him being “Sir!”d, about tactical saunas, and was an all around great guy.

title: AT 102: The Crossing Of The Delaware
content:
Got up and ready to head out, when we noticed a bear on the lawn of the hostel. Was a big one. Strange sighting, they normally just come into town for bin day, which is way off.
We had a whole send-off committee walking us to the PA-NJ border, which is just 0.3 miles from the hostel on the bridge over the Delaware river. Buckeye Boy’s first AT miles in a long time.
Said our farewells at the border and were in New Jersey. Hopefully a lot less rocky nonsense in NJ.
Passed the Delaware Water Gap Recreation Area, which was pretty much shut down due to bear activity. AT thru hikers were allowed to pass though, so no problems there.
Met Foodtruck, Swiss Chris and company again after the climb out of the recreation area, then cruised along, leapfrogging them for the next few hours.
Passed a big rattlesnake at a lake shore.
After 14 miles Turmerics parents and Buckeye Boy were waiting for us with trail magic. Apparently there were quite a few people on trail that came through. Apple juice was a big hit.
Got shuttled back into town, showered, then dinner at the BBQ place. The smoked stuff was very much delicious.
Afterwards we picked up Prepper, who had decided to slackpack the last section in PA southbound. Wasn’t too hard on his knees fortunately.
Then a little bit of hanging out, and off to bed.

title: AT 74: Open Arms Hostel
content:
Another nice weather day. Stopped for lunch at a resort type place.
Got some good views before getting down to Luray. Got rained on shortly, but no problem with a hostel waiting for us.
Did a short stint on bikes to get ice cream and go to the local outfitter. Did a late night resupply trip to Walmart with Allison, then off to bed with no plans of getting out early tomorrow.

title: AT 20: Sunshine Ridgeline Snow Showers
content:
Crisp morning, no snow for now. Lot’s of ridgeline walking with cold, windy, but sunny weather.
Got to the next shelter at around 15:00 and decided to push the 6 miles to the next. When we went off, the weather turned a little. Sun and snow showers for the next two hours.
Stopped at Siler Bald Shelter for the evening. Weather got better, but it’s really cold. Saw a turkey and deer right beside the shelter.
Built a big fire in the shelters fireplace and dried our wet clothes over it.
Tomorrow: Clingmans Dome with even colder and stronger winds forecasted, thats going to be a fun hike.

title: AT 124: Vermont
content:
Finished the climb up Mt Greylock. Got breakfast on the way from Bacon Wrap, who cooked up eggs and ham at a parking lot.
Visited the monument on top, then down the mountain again. Met up with Buckeye in Williamstown, got trail magic donuts there.
Went on to the Vermont Border, the start of the Long Trail, which we will follow for a 100 miles. Trail instantly turned muddy.
Shuttled back to town with Pokey, who supplied us with sandwiches and Gatorade. Split a motel room with Maggs, to wait out the rain that was forecast for the night.
More: Soaking feet in bear can.

title: AT 166: Big Miles Again
content:
Got up early again, and out of camp as well. Had a food drop arranged with Shaw’s at Jo Mary Road, so we had to be on time. Got to the drop off place an hour early, relaxed for a bit, dried shoes and socks.
When Poet arrived, we dumped our resupply into the packs, and on we went. Terrain is very flat and cruisy.
Decided to do 22 miles today, to set us up nicely for the Katahdin summit day. Got our first good view of Katahdin towering over one of the many Maine lakes.
Arrived at Nahmakanta Lake way after dark and two hours of night hiking. Feels good doing big miles again.

title: AT 57: Trail Magic Night Hiking
content:
Broke down camp and were just ready to hike out, when cars were pulling in to the parking area beside our spot. With a grill on a trailer.
Ended up getting legendary trail magic from Survivor, Tadpole, and support. They thru hiked in 2019 and have been doing trail magic at this very spot ever since once a year. Good timing. We ended up getting out of there at noon.
Aiming to go over McAfee Knob that evening that was a little late. Did Dragon’s Tooth, where we ate the sandwiches we packed out from Survivor. Gruelling hike down from there.
Then on to McAfee Knob, which we summited at around 22:15 in pitch blackness. Didn’t find the knob immediately, but got there eventually.
Went 0.5 miles further and set up camp at the Pig Farm Site, aiming for a 5 AM hike back to the Knob for sunrise shots.

title: AT 155: Saddleback
content:
Got egg sandwiches from Steve, said our goodbyes, then on trail again.
Did the Saddleback ridge, which had amazing views above treeline. Reminiscent of Franconia.
In the evening did an hour of night hiking and set up tent on an old fire road.

title: AT 143: Setting Up Washington
content:
Left the pond and climbed down into Crawford Notch. The climb out of there is basically the start of climbing Washington.
Did Mount Jackson, then went on to Mizpah Spring Hut, where we arrived at about 2:30. The hut croo told us that hiking further up is not advisable, as space at Lake Of The Clouds would not be available. Called it an early day then, got cold leftovers from the hut, and set up tent at the Nauman Tentsite.
Lot’s of weekenders around, as it’s the Labour Day Weekend. Tomorrow then an early start and up and over Mount Washington.

title: AT 52: Slackpacking Into Pearisburg
content:
Woods Hole is so awesome, we decided not to spend the next night in Pearisburg, but to extend the stay. Even got Buckeye Boy into the hostel vortex. What initially was just a means to avoid the dry stretch on the ridge turned out to be an exceptionally vibey place.
Breakfast was one of the best in my life. Fresh bread, apple butter, two kinds of oatmeal dishes, broccoli spinach eggs, orange juice, freshly roasted coffee.
Organized a slackpack into Pearisburg/shuttle back to the hostel and did the 12 miles just before a thunderstorm started.
At the trailhead just out of town we got the best trail magic yet from Dave, who has family on trail right now. He set up a build-your-taco station out of the back of his truck. After eating two of the tacos it started pouring; helped pack the food back into the truck, then left for town.
Got a ride into town by the host of a local hostel, resupplied at Food Lion, then back via shuttle (Honey Bun) to Woods Hole for dinner.
Ate probably too much, but the homemade food is just to die for. Lentils, rice, fresh bread, broccoli from the garden.

title: AT 2: Rain Finally
content:
Woke up to a light drizzle and a foggy forest.
Today another short hike. Very misty the first couple hours. Found mint and squirrels. Did eight miles to Gooch Gap Shelter, and only got rained on once. Won’t be the last rain.
Rain/Thunderstorm forecast for tonight. Shelter’s full and cosy.
Day before yesterday someone stole eight foodbags from the shelters bear box in the night. One of the guys here thought about hiding in the box for the night to safeguard them.

title: AT 11: Albert Mountain
content:
Woke up kinda cold, temperature was probably in the thirties. Was sunny, though. Strange feeling putting on sunscreen while shivering.
Albert Mountain was a steep climb; up there: the unofficial 100 mile marker on the firewatch tower.
Tonight lows of 33 are forecast, will be a shivering night.
Tomorrow we plan to resupply in Franklin, currently fantasizing about town food.
More: Privy window, Rock Gap Shelter.

title: AT 39: Zero Day
content: Lazy day. Hitchhiked to Food City to resupply, treated our clothes with Permethrin, cooked fancy dinner.

title: AT 36: 400 Miles Waterfalls
content:
Got an excellent breakfast at The Station; pancake, potatoes, bacon, scone, gravy, coffee. Got a short shuttle drive from Dave back to trail.
Planned a lot of miles, but with small elevation changes today. Passed the 400 mile marker early in the day.
Many waterfalls on the way, followed the Elk River for a short while. Good weather, flowering roses, butterflies.

title: AT 159: Into Rain
content:
Rain stopped in the morning, packed up, got trail magic for breakfast. While drinking coffee, a moose walked past. Now that’s a nice beginning of the day.
Hiked on, now on the flatter part of the Maine section of the trail. Rained on and off the whole day, so the trail got muddier and muddier.
Got to camp quite early, set up tent. Rain was steady now and lasted the whole night.

title: AT 49: Ridge Walks
content:
Broke down camp early and started the day with the climb up Chestnut Knob. Weather started out wet and foggy. The shelter up there is one of the sturdier ones, made completely out of stone and with a door to boot.
Weather cleared up while we were up there. Very nice views of the valley.
On the way down we met Corn Dog, Cool Dad, and Toto, who were slackpacking southbound for the day.
Then a long stretch of ridge walking with partially steep dropoffs. Very rocky ridge, which makes for great scenery, but poor hiking. Ridge walking is fun though everytime.
Made our way to Laurel Creek, where we set up tent near the creek. Washed ourselves in the creek (cold, but felt really good afterwards).
Met Mimi there, who did organize a cupcake and wine, celebrating her mate Six Pack’s birthday. Then quick dinner and off to bed.

title: AT 53: Slackpacking Hb
content:
Great breakfast again in Woods Hole. Got a shuttle back to town from Honey Bun and slackpacked out from Pearisburg.
Another ridge walk without water up top, but with great views sprinkled in. Met a lot of SOBO slackpackers today, including Mimi.
Thunderstorm started right at the descent; basically ran down the mountain. Did the old trailrunner trick and took my shirt off, so it couldn’t get wet.
Got shuttled back by Broccoli Rob to Honey Buns farm, who had invited us to stay for the night. Set up camp in his barn. Home cooked dinner with Honey Bun and his mate Tulsa on his porch. Meatloaf made from homegrown beef, corn, beans with bacon, mashed potatoes, all made by Momma Honey Bun. All around great evening.

title: AT 134: Marathon
content:
Woke up very early and headed out of the shelter at 7:00. Planned an 18 mile day, and wanted to shuttle forward about nine miles to Hanover from there, because we had a place to stay there for tonight.
At 10:00 we decided that we could make it into Hanover by hiking if we really pushed. After another ten hours of hiking and just the most necessary breaks in between, we ended up in Hanover at 8 PM. Our first and probably last marathon. Crossed into New Hampshire today on the last mile, as Hanover is just on the NH side of the VT/NH border.
Got picked up by Wren, who together with her husband Jon hosted us very graciously in their home. Got home cooked meals, a shower, nice beds.
More: Maple sap lines, soaking feet in a stream.

title: AT 77: Play Me The Virginia Blues
content:
First day without rain for a while. Got the Canadian wildfire haze though.
Did 18 miles today, the last few were a slog. Turmeric almost got hit by a large branch falling down, which fortunately got tangled up and didn’t actually touch her.
Set up tent at a shelter. Tomorrow we’ll tackle the Virginia Rollercoaster, which will be even more sloggy.

title: AT 68: Short Day Into Waynesboro
content:
Ate Banana Pudding for breakfast. Found some elderberry bushes in bloom and decided to take some flowers.
Today just a short day into Waynesboro, where we stayed at Stanimals. Good company there.
Everything in walkable distance, got Subway and did resupply at Walmart.
Did a little bit of cleaning and washing, had healthy dinner (!), then off to bed. Cooked up a bit of elderflower syrup just before bed.

title: AT 54: Zero Day
content:
Woke up in HBs barn, decided to accept the offer to stay for another day and take a zero then and there.
Planned to do nothing important, took a short shopping tour into town with Tulsa, then sat on the porch for several hours doing absolutely nothing.
That’s the life.
Got another home made dinner (spaghetti and meatballs), cheesecake and ice cream as dessert.

title: AT 25: Max Patch Thunderstorms
content:
The big thing today was Max Patch, which is a quite exposed bald with excellent views all around.
Made it there by noon and way before the weather finally turned bad. Very windy on top. Has a slight Black Forest vibe. Shame they closed it down for camping.
The shelter we’d liked to stay at was already occupied, so we decided to go on further and camp on Bluff Mountain. Every mile today is one less to Hot Springs tomorrow.
Decided not to camp on top, but went on down several hundred feet to get out of the worst of the rain tonight.
Thunderstorm started right as I set up my tent and got me soaking wet. Constant rain since then. First stress test for the tent in rain/wind. Right now it’s kinda cozy in here; let’s see how this goes.
Tomorrow a short day into Hot Springs, where a hostel bed is waiting for us.
Album of the day: High & Hungrig 3.
More: Chipmunks, who are very much not shy animals, ramen dinner in the vestibule.

title: AT 76: Exit Shenandoah
content:
Last day in Shenandoah. Started late, Turmeric wasn’t feeling very fit in the morning. Did put in the miles though.
A rainstorm caught us around noon and lasted for an hour, then the weather got better. Stopped for late lunch, after which we caught a second wind. Weather got outright nice.
Got peach tea from a guy doing trail magic at the road crossing into Front Royal. After that two hours left to the Jim and Mollie Denton Shelter.
Nicest shelter ever. Porch, dining gazebo, flowers, and a shower. Shared the shelter just with Buckeye Boy. Few people tenting/hammocking as well.

title: AT 86: Into Yankee Land
content:
Good weather, with showers in the afternoon. Did an extended lunch break at Penn Mar, then shortly after crossed the Mason-Dixon Line into Pennsylvania.
Terrain really got rocky, the stories about PA may be true after all.

title: AT 84: Slowly Starting Hiking Again
content:
Quick starter hike out of Cross Trails. Slackpacked about nine miles, then back to the hostel again. Hiking without Buckeye Boy feels weird.
Started at the Potomac on a nice, flat section; then up into the woods again. Ended the hike at Gathland State Park, then shuttled back with Benny.

title: AT 149: Mahoosic
content:
Started the day with Turmeric rolling her ankle, then continued with the hardest mile on trail.
Mahoosic Notch is a mile of random, fridge-to-car-sized boulders, where you have to scramble over and under and through. Took us about two hours and twenty minutes for about 0.9 miles. Was fun at times, and we had dry conditions, which was very welcome.
After that, the climb out of the notch was one of the steepest on trail. At the end of the day we were pretty done for.
Got into the Barn, being shuttled by Kitchen Sink. Got spaghetti and meatballs there, which Honey had cooked for dinner.

title: AT 157: Hurricane Watch
content:
Forecast had hurricane warnings, so we decided to sit it out in the hostel. Very nice thing, the Maine Roadhouse. Jen and Jen, who run it, are awesome as well.
Full house here, as a lot of people got out of the hurricane. Not a lot of weather coming through here in the valley. We got nice sunset views again though.
Did a resupply run in the hostel’s school bus, ate a lot of stuff. Very enjoyable stay. Good crew here; PBJ, Marty and wife decided to zero here as well.

title: AT 15: Rainy Day At Noc
content:
Lazy day at the NOC. Didn’t do much besides doing laundry and getting junky food.
Stayed out of the rain. Bought a replacement Sawyer, arch support inlays, and tape for my foot. Kinda seems like I just buy stuff instead of getting rid of it.
Got tele-medical advice regarding my ankle; seems like what I should do is give it some rest, which isn’t really on the table. Apparently nothing too bad though. Let’s see if Vitamin I and tape is up to the job. Thanks to all the people who support me!
It’s supposed to rain heavily tonight, hopefully tomorrow the worst will be over. It’s a big climb out of the valley, and in a few days time we’ll be in the Smokies.

title: AT 6: The First Long Day
content:
The bear can was found where it was left and we did leave Low Gap Shelter.
Planned a long day today: 4200 ft ascend, 3100 feet descent in 15.3 miles.
The day was somewhat more challenging than anticipated. The elevation changes were quite exhausting. Arrived at Tray Mountain Shelter late in the evening.
The campsite is really good, views in all directions, elevation is about 4200 ft. Ate a quick meal, then sleep.

title: AT 22: Big Trees Big Days
content:
Cold night, woke up to frost on the ground. The sun was out though and made getting up easy.
Due to rain forecasted for tomorrow afternoon we decided to make a big push to Cosby Knob Shelter twenty miles ahead. That could get us out of the Smokies by then. Started early, put in the miles. First twenty mile day! Almost all of it above 5000 ft, with a lot less wind than yesterday and sunny weather.
Along the way: Lot’s of ridgeline walking, views, snowy trails, more old growth forest.

title: AT 163: Entering The Wilderness
content:
Packed up, and got breakfast. Coffee, eggs, bacon, potatoes, blueberry pancakes.
Did say some goodbyes to people zeroing/getting out later there (Corndog, Siren, Neo, Mudbag, Sunshade). Got our food drop bucket to the right people, then off out of Monson.
Did road walk out of town and connected back to the trail quite a bit into the wilderness. Decided to go further to Cloud Pond Lean To, passed the 2100 mile marker (last one on trail!).
Had a sunset on top of Barren Mountain that could hold up with the best ones. Night hiked for the last hour into the shelter, set up quickly, then to bed.

title: AT 120: To Dalton
content:
Got up early, watched the sunrise over the lake, then got served pancakes and coffee by Vlobster.
Got out at eightish, said goodbye to Buckeye, and went on our way. Long day into Dalton, and with rain threatening, we didn’t do many breaks but hiked on and on.
Little bit of mud, a lot of roots. Training for Vermont. Fell completely flat on my belly at one time, tripping over some sneaky root or rock.
Arrived in town at 5:30 after 21 miles of walking. Went to the ice cream shop (cinnamon, orange, in a waffle cone), then to a gas station for quick junk resupply (hot dogs, breakfast sandwiches, Duke’s).
Got a ride to the Zero Day Hostel by Pokey, a trail angel based in Great Barrington.

title: AT 69: Zero Day
content:
Took a zero at Stanimals. Got pancakes in the morning. Lazed around all day.
Went to a Mexican restaurant, and to Walmart again.
Next few days will be Shenandoah, which should be easy miles.

title: AT 117: Bear Mountain Mount Everett
content:
Chumbawamba and PBJ decided to slackpack the next section, so we opted to do that as well.
Drizzled a lot today and a lot of fog/clouds. Had two big peaks to cross, with slabby rocks and slick descents, so just having a light pack was much appreciated.
Crossed into Massachusetts today.
Leapfrogged PBJ and Chumbawamba the whole day and made it to the pickup point just before dark.
Shuttled back to Vanessa’s for pizza and sleep.

title: AT 80: Zero Day
content:
Zero day. Made pancakes for breakfast. Organized food supply, did digital chores.
Shuttled for resupply, got ice pops served by Walmart, played a game of chess. Had a nice little walk along the Potomac.
Made big dinner with pasta, veggies, and burgers, then got some pulled pork for second dinner.

title: AT 8: Zero Day
content:
Did a Zero Day today. Gotta get them in while the accommodation is as nice as here.
Did nothing all day but sitting on the couch and lazing around.
Got soup from the hiker box for lunch and pizza for dinner. Campfire in the evening, then off to bed.

title: AT 91: Duncannon 1:
content:
Made our way to Duncannon, where a resupply package should be waiting. Went to the 7-11 first, then to the outfitter where the package had been mailed to.
The outfitter was closed down for the day, because of some of the owners personal reasons. As we Need access to the package, we decided to wait in town and pick it up tomorrow.
Went to the Wednesday free church hiker feed at the Christ Lutheran Church, where we got spaghetti, meatballs, salad, and dessert. Turmeric even got gluten free spaghetti. Thanks CLC!
Spent the night at The Church Along The Way, who lets hikers stay in the air conditioned basement. Very nice and clean. Thanks TCATW!

title: Yosemite 3: Grand Canyon Of The Tuolumne
content:
This morning, after a short mile or so, we arrived at Glen Aulin, an established camp, where one could book a night in a tent-hut, if so inclined. The real kicker was the toilet and the drinking water, open for anyone, though.
After a quick stop there, we crossed the PCT again (this time felt more real, ’cause we hiked in…). Then on, into the canyon.
Started out pretty shallow, but after following the Tuolumne River for several hours, along waterfalls tiny and big, the walls started to get higher and higher.
Saw one big rattlesnake, big trees, humongous pinecones, chunky lizards, a lot of waterfalls and hundreds of feet of granite wall beside us.
In the afternoon we found a stellar camp site above the river, set up camp and called it a day. Very enjoyable thing not having to do stupid miles every day and being able to relax a bit in the evening.

title: AT 105: In The Woods Again
content:
Checked out of Cobmin Ridge late and discovered that Airquotes and Iceman had been there for the last night. They had Airquotes dad driving support for them the last days.
Got Buckeye Boy set up in the car, then drove off to the trailhead. Got trail magic there from Moose, who had an awesome spread of food and gear there.
Did a relaxed slackpack to High Point State Park, which marks the highest point in NJ. Buckeye Boy met us there to give us back our backpacks, then 0.5 miles more to the High Point Shelter, which we had to our own.
More: Turkey in the wild.

title: AT 61: Blue Ridge Parkway
content:
Left Survivor’s house reluctantly. He shuttled us back to the Daleville trailhead and we were on our way.
First few miles out of town felt sluggish and slow. Got better once we got up and out of the humidity.
Passed the 1/3rd marker today. Getting closer to Katahdin!
Got trail magic from Don The Appleman, then hiked on to Bobblets Gap Shelter. Walked mostly along the Blue Ridge Parkway, a tourist road with good views of the mountains/valleys.
A lot of trash cans there for the car tourists, which is always welcome.

title: AT 42: Walking Into Damascus
content:
Plan for today: Easy miles into Damascus. Should be all ridge walking in a generally downward direction.
Walked through a section where a bear seems to have taken up residency at a shelter. Made for a little bit of tension. We had to get water there, so Turmeric and Torch guarded our packs while Buckeye Boy and I went down for water. No bear sighting today though, which is good.
Crossed from Tennessee into Virginia today, which is the fourth state on this journey. We’ll stay here in VA for quite a while now.
Strange feeling walking into a town you know already. A lot more empty though.
Did a crappy resupply at DG, which hasn’t been restocked since traildays. No flour tortillas and no hot chocolate will make for sad meals.
Noticed the mesh on the back of my backpack ripping. Asked at the outfitter what to do about this, they said they’d ask Osprey about that.
Choice of town food today was Subway (two footlongs).
To get back to Warrens place we got two hitches out of town. Damon took us halfway there, then Debbie got her pickup truck and drove us the last two miles. She let us ride in the back, a welcome first.
Back at Warrens place we got into our familiar bunkhouse and went to bed.

title: AT 78: Rollercoaster
content:
The Rollercoaster. Pointless ups and downs for the whole day. No sense of accomplishment whatsoever when you get up the next hill.
Passed the 1000 mile marker. Soon we’ll be counting down the miles to Katahdin…
Turmeric did suffer a lot and isn’t feeling all too well. She powered through it though and we stopped right before the end of the Rollercoaster for the night.
Tomorrow will be easier terrain and the end of Virginia, so there’s something to look forward to.

The Rollercoaster. Pointless ups and downs for the whole day. No sense of accomplishment whatsoever when you get up the next hill.

Passed the 1000 mile marker. Soon we’ll be counting down the miles to Katahdin…

Turmeric did suffer a lot and isn’t feeling all too well. She powered through it though and we stopped right before the end of the Rollercoaster for the night.

Tomorrow will be easier terrain and the end of Virginia, so there’s something to look forward to.

title: AT 137: Arriving At The Whites
content:
Did relatively easy 15 miles from the Hexacuba Shelter to the Hikers Welcome Hostel. Resupplied in town, got a shower, grilled a pizza.
Tomorrow the first day in the White Mountains, we’ll be slackpacking Mount Moosilauke for starters.

title: AT 83: Fourth In Dc
content:
Shuttled to the next Metro station with Benny, then took the Red Line into DC.
Did a quick run to the best/most accessible sites there: Parade, National Archives, National Gallery Of Art, Washington Monument, White House, Fireworks. Very patriotic. Did see the Declaration of Independence, and van Gogh’s self portrait, but didn’t meet Joe Biden nor Captain America.
The tour didn’t do the city justice though. DC should be visited for a whole week at least. We’ll add it to the bucket list.

title: AT 48: The Quarter Marker
content:
Got up early and took an 8 AM shuttle back to trail. Trail conditions were quite muddy all day, but the sun did come out eventually.
Got to the quarter of the way marker today.
Did 20 miles, crossed an overflowing bridge, and forded a creek (bridge got washed out years ago). Wasn’t as bad as some people warned us, water barely got to our knees. Set up camp just on the other side.

title: AT 130: Little Rock Pond
content:
Left the Green Mountain House, where Chief and Jeff had flying the German flag for me today. Probably the most well run hostel so far.
Air seems to be hazy today. Made our way up Styles Peak. Turmeric has done this section southbound last year, which gives us a little local knowledge of the trail right now.
Ended the day at Little Rock Pond, where we stayed at the shelter with some locals out for a few days.

title: AT 127: Long Trail Miles
content:
Did 17 miles to Story Spring Shelter. Trail got a little less muddy, weather was ideal for hiking. No rain, no sun, cool enough that you need a jacket when stopping. No mosquitoes as well.
Were able to have lunch and a afternoon break at shelters, which are much more frequent along the Long Trail.
Met two LT SOBOers at the shelter, and a local lady with a small kid hiking. Two big dogs at the shelter, who left when it got dark.
Tomorrow probably rain, so the shelter is packed full.

title: AT 47: Rain Resupply
content:
Started the day in cool, steady rain. Fast hiking keeps one warm though. Cleared up after an hour or two.
Streams were high, crossing them did result in wet feet. Hiked to the Settler Museum just out of Atkins, where we got picked up for the ride into Marion/the hostel.
Bought a rain skirt and a new knife (with scissors!) at the outfitter below the hostel.
Then resupplied at the Walmart the first time since Atlanta. Was really great there, had anything you want and more (but no Spam in packets…). Should do this more often (DG resupply really sucks). Made a quick visit to the Ingles, which will probably be the last one on trail. Sad.
After that, dinner at Sonic. They have great food; ate my first corn dog there as well. Might not be the last one.
Did take a quick look at the Memorial Day display at the courthouse in town.
Then back to the hostel and the ordinary management of the packsplosion/resupply chaos.

title: AT 43: Walking Out Of Damascus
content:
Woke up at Warren’s place, made pancakes, walked to the gas station at the Divide Road junction and hitched a ride (technically two) into Damascus.
The outfitter told us to contact Osprey directly via phone, called them, they told me to email them. Hmmm.
Got out of Damascus shortly after noon. Trail goes up to the Grayson Highlands, so the going isn’t so easy as the last couple of days. But nothing too serious.
Did the last three miles on my own and camped beside the Virginia Creeper Trail. The Creeper Trail was a rail line once and is now a gently graded bicycle path. Very nice stretch of trail. Turmeric, Torch, and Buckeye Boy stayed at a shelter tonight.
Started raining soon after setting up my tent, but didn’t get wet.

title: AT 147: Summers Back
content:
Hot outside, even in the early morning. Did Mount Moriah in foggy but warm weather, then a sunny flat section to Route 2. Almost got heat stroke; was getting brain foggy already. After two liters of water and home made beef jerky from a weekender the heat stroke was a thing of the past.
Got to the 1900 mile marker around noon. Only 300 to go!
Passed by a dam, where Buckeye, Toto, and Mudbag were fishing and in the water; stayed there for a bit.
Hiked on to Trident Col Campsite, ate fancy camping meals, then off to bed.

title: AT 70: Shenandoah
content:
Got another pancake breakfast at Stanimals.
Then slackpacked into Shenandoah. Raining on and off. Filled out the backcountry permit and were on our way.
No views at all, but the trail is nicely graded. No water bars on the trails though. Trail and streams are indistinguishable at some times.
The trail in Shenandoah follows mostly the Skyline Drive, another tourist road built just for the views. Unfortunately the trail doesn’t get the views though. Some people walk the road to get the better views, but not us.
Didn’t get a place in the shelter that night and had to set up tent in the rain on uneven ground.

title: AT 115: Creek Crossings
content:
Having a goal in mind a few days out really helps with doing the miles. Got up early and did a relatively chill day of 17 miles.
Had to do a reroute, which put us into civilization a little. Stepped on a baseball field for the first time, then on a football field as well.
Had two more or less sketchy creek crossings. Gives you a free foot soak, which is always nice if the weather is hot.
Rolled into camp late and setup with Maggs. Lot’s of mosquitoes here, which made going to bed early easy.

title: AT 152: More Cabin Slackpacking
content:
Another slackpack today, over Old Blue Mountain and the Bemis Ridge.
Had rain threatening all day, but just a little sprinkle materialized all day.
Saw fresh moose poop, but not one moose. Strange birds in the trees though.
Best views at the end of the day, when we waited for our pick up.
Bonus: Maine magazines.

title: AT 1: A Short Hike Just What The Ranger Ordered
content:
Did a short day to Hawk Mountain Shelter. First day on the AT proper. With the rhododendron growing thick around the trail you get the “green tunnel” nickname of the trail. Trail is very pretty.
Staying in the shelter today, there’s a good crowd here. Started drizzling after I got here, very cozy inside.

title: AT 141: Franconia Ridge
content:
Got up, packed up, made pancakes, got out.
Hiked up to the ridge trail, did the blue blaze to Mount Liberty, from where we could see the start of the ridge. Then went on to the ridge proper. Summited Little Haystack, Lincoln, and Lafayette. Weather was stellar, but extremely windy and cold. A lot of tourists up here, which we are not used to. The ridge walk was out of this world. Best few miles on the AT.
Went on and over Garfield, where our goal for the day is. First time in one of the AMC campsites/shelter. Very nicely done; has a friendly caretaker (Peter), who got us the AMC thru hiker card, which gives us a heavy discount on the AMC facilities, and free soup in the huts.

title: AT 45: Grayson Highlands
content:
Woke up to a clear crisp morning, which turned into an overcast, windy day.
Passed the 500 mile marker in the morning. No ponies around, but great views from the sparser vegetated highland landscape. Looks almost Scandinavian.
Made our way to the Hurricane Shelter, which is packed full because the forecast calls for a lot of rain tonight.

title: AT 81: What About Second Zero Day
content:
Another batch of pancakes in the morning.
Got into Harper’s Ferry to get into the ATC visitor center and get our pic taken. Went from hiker #2476 in Amicalola down to #1121 in Harper’s Ferry. Strange that so many people haven’t arrived/checked in here (yet).
Got new shoes at the outfitter. Switched from Lone Peak 6s to the 7s. Let’s see how this goes.
Shuttled back to the hostel with the Rollercoaster’s own Trailboss himself. Told us that prior to the construction of the Rollercoaster there was a 13 mile stretch of roadwalking. Kind of makes the experience more bearable in hindsight.
Buckeye Boy’s foot is kinda shot. He can’t walk more than a few yards. May have to see someone medically qualified for this eventually.
We decided to stay for a little longer and try to get into DC on the Fourth. In the afternoon I got to do some digital chores and called home after having not done so for a long time.
Dinner today was pasta and veggies again, did eat all of my cheese out of my bear can with it.

title: AT 82: Waiting For The Fourth
content:
Called home and did some of the digital chores that were left.
Did a resupply for tomorrow. Buckeye Boy’s foot is not in the best shape. He won’t be hiking out with us anytime soon.
Watched a thunderstorm rolling in in the evening.

title: AT 110: Car Troubles Bear Mountain Bypass
content:
Another morning at the movie theater. Took the car in to the shop for a tune up and walked around town for quite a while.
Hit Burger King (good breakfast), a bakery (good choccy croissants) and a wrap shop (good toasted wraps).
Got the car back in good order (changed spark plugs, cleaned the idle air control valve). Then went back to the movie theater to pack up, and Buckeye drove us back to the closed down State Park highway exit.
Walked back to the trail and decided not to go over Bear Mountain, but use the current bypass, which is a bit of a roadwalk. Road damage and construction work on the roadwalk.
Decided to set up camp in one of the park’s picnic pavilions, which we did after dark as to not being seen. Guarantees an early wake up time as well…

title: AT 144: The Presidentials
content:
Got up at 4:30 expecting a long day. Left Mizpah Spring Hut and hiked on to Lakes Of The Clouds.
Got a bowl of scrambled eggs and burnt pancakes for second breakfast, then on to Mount Washington. Was an easy climb up there from the hut. A lot of dayhikers and weekenders around, as it is Labour Day Weekend.
Up at the summit we got the quick pic with the sign, then went to the visitor center and got some food. Bit jarring not having a summit to ourselves.
Went on to do the Presidential Traverse, staying above treeline for some eight miles more. Got soup and brownies with Ten Years at Madison Spring Hut, before summiting Madison. Afterwards a long scrambly descent below treeline and set up tent at the Osgood Campsite.
Were in and out of the clouds the whole day, which made for great views, even if we didn’t have any from Washington itself. Was a long and hard day, and we’re almost finished with the Presidentials now. Only five flat miles left for tomorrow, then on to the Wildcats.

title: AT 16: Rainy Day Out Of Noc
content:
Well rested we got out of the NOC; breakfast out of a kitchen was a big plus. About 4000 ft of ascent today, a big push out of the valley.
It did rain a lot. Trail conditions could be better, but it’s easier going up a muddy, wet trail than going down.
At the top of Cheoah Bald the weather did clear up though. Great views all around.
Camped for the night at Locust Cove Gap. The tent is tucked away underneath some rhododendron bushes. Could not locate any locusts.

title: AT 3: Making Camp In Cocaine Bear Country
content:
Upon waking up, we found out that indeed, our food was still there. Happiness all around.
Rolled my ankle/foot about 2 miles in the day. Not a good thing, and decided to leave the ascent (and descent) of Blood Mountain as a task for future me.
Seen on the way: Trillium flowers, snails, fog wafting over the trail.
Stopped shortly before Blood Mountain, where Bret and Mark, two former firefighters, found me. They managed to lighten the spirits with a little help from our friend Jim. They left me with more food than I came in, and were all around stellar guys.
Bad weather forecast for Blood Mountain tomorrow, let’s wait and see.

title: AT 37: Trail Days DAY 1:
content:
Short day to the next road crossing at mile 420. Rhododendron bushes will bloom soon. At the road we got off trail and shuttled into Damascus/Warrens place.
Good weather, many known faces in Damascus. A lot of great food and goodies there, and gear companies galore. Saw Heather Anderson there. Won a Granite Gear fanny pack in a raffle.
Got a Philly Cheese Steak, a hamburger, a hot dog, chips w/ salsa, ice cream/apple cookie, a banana, melon slices, muesli bars, peanuts.
In the evening we went back to Warrens place, Groundhog and Buckeye Boy went back into town again to stay the night in Tent City.
