Short day to the next road crossing at mile 420. Rhododendron bushes will bloom soon. At the road we got off trail and shuttled into Damascus/Warrens place.

Good weather, many known faces in Damascus. A lot of great food and goodies there, and gear companies galore. Saw Heather Anderson there. Won a Granite Gear fanny pack in a raffle.

Got a Philly Cheese Steak, a hamburger, a hot dog, chips w/ salsa, ice cream/apple cookie, a banana, melon slices, muesli bars, peanuts.

In the evening we went back to Warrens place, Groundhog and Buckeye Boy went back into town again to stay the night in Tent City.

title: AT 111: State Park Camping
content:
Got up very early, to avoid being seen in the pavilion by State Park Rangers.
Crossed the bridge over the Hudson River, then up into the hills again.
The last stretch of the day went over an old minecart track for about two miles, which was a welcome change in trail conditions. No ups and downs at all, even three foot drops were nicely built up with a few hundred years old stonework.
Ended the day at Clarence Fahnestock State Park, to which we got a hitch from trail. Met up with Buckeye there again, pitched our tent and had a little campfire.

title: AT 129: Bromley Mountain
content:
Day started windy and wet, but the mud was not as bad as the few hours of rain tonight made it out to be.
Crossed Vermont Route 11/30, where we got nice trail magic.
Climbed Bromley, which was a relaxed 1500 foot climb without mud. On top we got into the open warming hut for half an hour. Had working outlets, a dryer, and heaters inside.
Met Marty, PBJ, and Secret Sauce on the mountain, who were slackpacking southbound.
Did another two miles down the mountain (a lot of mud there). Got picked up by Chief, who shuttled us into town for resupply, then to the Green Mountain House, where Turmeric had a resupply package waiting.

title: AT 30: Rain Platinum Blazing
content:
Started late, went for a frozen pizza at a hostel three miles in. Was a rather Southern experience…
After that, a steep climb up in the heat, followed by a change in weather for the worse. Light thunderstorm followed by strong rain. The umbrella I bought in Hot Springs really helped in the rain, but I have to get a system going to attach it to the pack so I have my hands free for the poles.
Decision by committee got us a night in Nature’s Inn Hostel after unsuccessfully waiting out the rain under the highway bridge at Sam’s Gap. I’ll answer to “Platinum Blazer” soon probably.
The hostel is really good though, the showers alone are better than everything I’ve ever seen. And there’s a fireplace in the common room (!). Got homemade pulled pork for dinner.
This will result in extra miles tomorrow, but that’s future me’s problem. An umbrella fixation system has been cobbled together with string and hiker box supplies, seems to be sturdy. Tomorrow we’ll see if it holds up when used in anger.

title: AT 108: What About Second Barbie
content:
Broke down camp in the movie theater and got ready for another NY day.
Big rocks, open forest, even a waterfall. Some beaver boggy ponds as well.
In the evening we returned to the movie theater, which was just too convenient to not to go to again. Half watched Barbie for a second time. Camped in the car this night, while Buckeye tented in the hiker area.

title: AT 41: Ridge Walking
content:
Getting into Damascus tomorrow requires big miles today, so we left early. No bear activity in the campsite.
Most of the day was spent on the ridge over Lake Watauga, which made easy miles possible.
Got into camp at around six. Met Mighty Blue and his friends there, who were on their way into Damascus as well.

title: AT 33: Unaka Mountain Old Apple Orchard
content:
Got a good deal on a slackpack and out of Uncle Johnny’s just with day packs.
Met Brother Tom on trail, who’s doing trail magic on weekdays. Got sweet tea, brownies, an apple. Thank you!
Climbed Unaka Mountain while it was getting foggier by the minute. Very atmospheric in the dense spruce forest; moss everywhere.
Rain started seriously after the summit. Ran down the mountain to the shelter, trail running might be fun after all. Went further to Iron Gap, where we got our backpacks back.
Turmeric, Torch, and Toto decided to get a hostel, Tim and I went on to the Old Apple Orchard site. Very nice spot with old apple trees in a clearing in the woods. PBJ and Groundhog are here as well.
Set up tents, ate dinner, bedtime.

title: AT 58: Mcafee Knob Virginia Triple Crown
content:
Got up early after a night of cowboy camping. Left at 5:30 to go back to McAfee Knob, arrived at the not-McAfee-Knob-ledge, where about 10 people were waiting for sunrise.
Went over to McAfee Knob, where we were completely alone except for a couple with their dog. Got a lot of pictures there. Canadian wildfire haze made for a great sunrise.
Had a memorable breakfast up there.
Left camp very late, hiked over the Tinker Cliffs, and with that completed the Virginia Triple Crown. Good views back to McAfee from there.
Went to Lambert’s Meadow Shelter, took a nap, waited for Buckeye Boy, whose birthday it is today. Mimi and Airquotes there as well.
Good times.

title: AT 165: First View Of Katahdin
content:
Last significant mountain in the wilderness coming up today. Was an easier one, were on White Cap before noon.
Got our first view of Katahdin from there. Looks like a big one. Extremely faint in the haze though. Walked here all the way from Georgia, and now we’ll be there in a few days.
Got down from the mountain and into the plains, climbed another smaller hill. Set up tent at Crawford Pond, ate dinner on the beach, then to bed early.
Tomorrow we’ll get our food drop from Shaw’s at 11 AM, then the last stretch to Katahdin begins.

title: AT 168: The Setup
content:
Got up reasonably early and hiked the 3.5 miles to Abol Bridge and the sign up for the Birches campsite. Got two of the last spaces there. Went back to the camp store, got junk food and coffee, got rid of our trash, had a good time with the hiker trash there.
Went on into the park at 10 AM, took our time to get to Katahdin Stream. Did our last shoes off creek crossing, took three breaks at the creek, enjoyed a relaxed day.
At the Birches the ranger gave us our permits and some advice, Johnny K brought fruit and took our trash. He also offered us a ride out of Baxter the next day, which was much appreciated.
Had one of the Birches’ shelters for us alone this night, and went to bed early.

title: AT 55: Virginia Ridgelines Trail Magic
content:
Leftover cheesecake for breakfast, then Tulsa drove us back to the trailhead. Was an exceptional stay at HBs.
Today 18 miles over two ridges. Got trail magic in the first one, so the climb up the second one was a breeze. Passed a burnt down section, did talk to one of the Nomads for a minute, saw a deer.
Got to Laurel Creek Shelter and met up with Torch, Groundhog, and Mimi. Leftovers from yesterday as dinner.

title: Yosemite 5: Up Up And Away
content:
Ten miles out of the canyon and back to the car today. Got up early, to get in as much hiking as possible, before the sun makes going up the steep walls miserable.
Worked out beautifully, with us being halfway up the canyon at 9 in the morning. Even found a flowing creek for water there.
Despite a lot of elevation gain we both felt pretty good, made good progress, and arrived at the car at about 1 PM. After cold drinks out of the bear box (V8, vroom vroom) we headed down into Yosemite Valley. Very impressive down there, even after 5 days of in the back country.
Set up camp at Upper Pines, got a sandwich (more like two) at the deli, catched a shower at the Village (very much needed).
Early to bed, and then tomorrow: Half Dome.

title: AT 146: Wildcat
content:
Did the Wildcats today. Started at 7:30 at the hostel, shuttled to Pinkham Notch. Got our power banks out of the hiker room, and met Toto there.
Hiked up Wildcat D, which is the steepest climb on the AT. Was fun, but slow. Stopped for second breakfast at the ski lift. Then over the rest of the Wildcat summits, and then down again.
Visited Carter Notch Hut, the last of the AMC huts on the AT. The croo gave us a big tray of leftover lasagna for dinner. Got water there as well, then up Carter Dome.
The climb was similar to Wildcat D, so it took a while till we got to camp. Had to night hike for an hour, doing some of the sketchier descents on trail yet.
Got into camp at around 8:30, set up tent, ate, washed up a little, then to bed. Was a rough day, with only 13 miles, but about 5800 feet of ascent.

title: AT 164: Mid Wilderness Magic
content:
Left Cloud Pond early and started the day with some deceptively strenuous sections. No big climbs, but a lot of smaller up and downs. Very picturesque swampy sections as well.
In the afternoon came to the West Branch Pleasant River crossing, which could have been one of the bad ones. After arriving we saw that it was just about knee deep. Very happy, as the alternative route around that would have cost us half a day at least.
Before crossing we checked out some unexpected trail magic at Gulf Hagas trailhead parking. Was very nice, with hot dogs, snacks, sodas, trash.
After that we crossed the river, and hiked another five miles to Carl Newhall Lean To. Daybreak was set up there in the shelter, and Turmeric was able to return her tent stakes, which we had found abandoned on trail earlier.
More: Old plane wreckage in the forest/on trail (father and son pilots were able to hike out quite alive supposedly).

title: AT 142: White Mountain Views
content:
No famous climbs today, but really good views of famous things. Started the day with a climb down a literal waterfall; trails here can be really unreasonable.
Got a bowl of scrambled eggs in exchange for sweeping the floor at Galehead Hut, got some cake there, and hot chocolate.
Then up South Twin, from where Franconia Ridge, Mount Washington, and the rest of the Whites were all clearly visible. Much warmer and less windy today.
Then down again, and to Zealand Hut, where we got Chicken Soup and bread for first dinner.
Camped at Ethan Pond Shelter, where we just catched the sunset above the lake.

title: AT 96: Heroing
content:
Walked into Port Clinton at around noon. Wanted to check out Cabelas and Walmart, so we tried to catch the Cabelas shuttle, which didn’t work out.
Ended up calling a local shuttle driver, who ended up being Brian, the Regular Car Reviews guy on YT. Had a 1963 convertible taxi car in which we got to Cabelas.
Charged phones there, then took an Uber to Walmart, where we resupplied.
Back to the trail with Brian, and then: Our first time hiking out of town after resupplying. Did the climb out of town and set up tent on top of the ridge at Pocahontas spring.

title: AT 40: Waterfalls Bears
content:
Got shuttled back from Mountain City to the trailhead by Cindy.
First stop: Laurel Creek Falls, where we went for a quick dip in the river. Very refreshing.
Hiked on, passed Lake Watauga, crossed the dam.
Saw two bear cubs on the road, who disappeared when we made loud noises.
After setting up tent, Mother Bear appeared at the campsite. Wasn’t shy at all, and had the cubs with her; we did not like that, and broke down camp. Tent takedown was pretty quick with a bear watching from 20 yards away.
Hiked another mile to the next tent site and set up for good. Turmeric decided to spend the night in Boots Off Hostel and shuttled out, so it’s all Germans tonight.

title: AT 21: Its All Downhill From Here Boys And Girls
content:
Cold night. Some folks had their water bladders frozen in the morning. Put on mittens for the first time.
Made our way to Clingmans Dome, with an elevation of over 6600 ft the highest point on the AT. Lot’s of dayhikers there. The Dome also acts as the 200 mile marker. Less than 2000 miles to go!
Cold wind the whole day, despite sunny weather. Snow and ice on the ground in shadier places.
The old growth forest here is really something else. Fallen trees everywhere, dense growth, cathedral-like passages. Moss all over the landscape.
After straddling the North Carolina/Tennessee border for quite some time, the first official sign was at Newfound Gap.
Did the last three miles to Icewater Spring Shelter in the afternoon. Another cold night forecasted.

title: AT 63: To Glasgow
content:
Goal for today: Glasgow, VA.
Saw a radar dome, had to bushwhack around a snake guarding its den right on trail, passed the Guillotine.
Crossed the river into Glasgow on the footbridge and got shuttled to Stanimals in the Nastymobile.
Checked in, got out to resupply and eat at the pizza place. Had a nice little walk back to the hostel watching fireflies.

title: AT 160: Kennebec
content:
Woke up with condensation in the tent and wet quilts. Got up, crossed our first creek of the day (water up to knees).
Got into Pierce Pond Camp, where there was coffee and a wood stove. Dried out stuff, charged up a little, then on to the Kennebec.
Majorly sketchy creek crossings after the rain, trail is sometimes under water up to your knees.
Kennebec was crossed quickly in a canoe operated by Ferryman Matt.
After arriving at Holly Brook, we decided not to cross it. Way too sketchy. Had to backtrack 2.7 miles and then took a long roadwalk around the crossing.

Majorly sketchy creek crossings after the rain, trail is sometimes under water up to your knees.

Kennebec was crossed quickly in a canoe operated by Ferryman Matt.

After arriving at Holly Brook, we decided not to cross it. Way too sketchy. Had to backtrack 2.7 miles and then took a long roadwalk around the crossing.
meta_description: Woke up with condensation in the tent and wet quilts. Got up, crossed our first creek of the day (water up to knees). Got into Pierce Pond Camp, where there was coffee and a wood stove. Dried out stuff, charged up a little, then on to the Kennebec. Majorly sketchy creek crossings after the rain,…

title: AT 72: A Bit Of SUN 900: Miles
content:
Didn’t rain all day, which is a win. Sun even came out for a bit.
Passed the 900 mile marker.
At the end of the day we got off trail and went to a campground to dump trash. The groundskeeper offered us a free tentsite, which we happily accepted. Flat ground, a personal bear box, warm water…

title: AT 71: Rain In Shenandoah
content:
Another rainy day. Today there would have been views, but not in this weather. Too bad.
Around noon we stopped at one of the campgrounds to visit the campground store and the laundry facilities. Got some nasty microwave burgers and put our sleeping bags into the dryer for a minute.
Started to slather our feet in Vaseline, which works remarkably well to manage wet feet. Reapplied that at the laundry room as well.
Got into Pinefield Hut that night, so there’s that.

title: AT 131: Sights Set On Hanover
content:
Got up early and got out of camp. Nice view of the lake in the morning.
Planned for a long day and did just shy of 20 miles. Having set the goal of Hanover for Thursday evening helps putting in the miles.
Stopped at the Governor Clement Shelter after two late creek crossings and a little bit of night hiking. Not yet at 1700 miles, but under 500 to Katahdin left.

title: AT 19: Enter The Smokies
content:
Another morning in the Hilton. Charged the powerbank fully up in the restroom, cooked breakfast with gas from the hiker box. That’s the life. Decided to push my luck and try to enter the Smokies with the missing piece of skin on my foot
Short walk over to Fontana Dam, crossed the dam, entered the Smokies. Put our permits in the box, then started the long ascent to the ridge. Trails in the park are significantly better than the AT thus far. Better grading, less roots, less stones. Much more wind though.
Did a short stint further up to Shuckstack Lookout Tower, from where there were stunning views over the Smokies and Fontana Lake. Just for the low price of a terrifying climb up/down in really strong wind.
Felt good after the Zero the day before, and did 15 miles to Russell Field Trail Shelter. Now that’s a shelter! Has an in-shelter fireplace, skylights, and is made from stone. Had to hang my food for the first time, because the Smokies don’t allow for bear canisters.
Foot feels quite good, considering the mileage and elevation profile today. Next few days are forecasted to be really cold, maybe even snow. Let’s see how this goes.

title: AT 44: Uphill Walking
content:
Got up early and was on my way along the Virginia Creeper Trail. Nice bridges and wide path. Soon the AT got away from the Creeper Trail again, and the big climb up to the highlands started.
Got to Buzzard Rock at noon, rested for half an hour, then had an easier trail for the rest of the day.
Got really good trail magic at a road crossing. Gatorade, apples, bananas, peanut butter, cookies.
Got early to Thomas Knob Shelter. Has the nicest view from the water source on trail yet. Waited for the other three to arrive and had dinner and an apple in front of the shelter.
Another two Germans in the shelter tonight, we might be the majority right now.

title: AT 59: Good Times In Roanoke
content:
After meeting up with Buckeye Boy yesterday, we had just shy of 10 miles into town. Took our time to do that, stopped and smelled the roses. Scenic stretch with pine trees, nice trail, good views.
Came out of the woods at a highway, which was a little bit jarring. Short road walk to the outfitter, where Turmeric had a package waiting. Got a summer shirt there as well.
Then resupply at the Kroger/ABC store. While waiting outside and eating late lunch, two separate people came up and left us trail magic. One six pack of beer, one fruit platter. The generosity of random people here is a little bit surreal.
Got picked up by Survivor, who had offered to host us a few days ago. He has a nicely renovated old house in Roanoke and hosts a lot of people there. Had a nice evening with homemade food and nice conversation. Prof X was there as well.
After doing laundry and getting ice cream with Survivor and Prof X, fell into our beds.

title: AT 116: Salisbury
content:
Passed the 1500 mile marker today. Stayed for a bit at a waterfall, then went on to Salisbury.
Did a short resupply at the local grocery store. Very preppy town, and people were very friendly to us hiker trash.
Got a bunk at Vanessa’s, where Chumbawamba, PBJ, Cheeks, and Secret Sauce stayed as well.

title: Yosemite 1: White Wolf To Ten Lakes
content:
Got up early (thanks Pacific Time) and packed up our palatial car camping tent. Off of the BLM land and onto the NPS one.
Got gas around Lee Vining (European prices), then up to Tioga pass.
Entered the National Park and, for the meme, set foot on the PCT, which crosses the road at Tuolumne Meadows. Now we both have set foot on the three big trails; that surely must be worth a micro triple crown…
At Olmsted Point we got good views of Half Dome and the Sub Dome; things yet to come. Got a quick pic off of the road from Tenaya Lake, then on to the ranger station.
Got our backcountry permit at the ranger station, and drove to White Wolf, where our loop starts/ends. Put the extra food into the bear boxes there, then were on our way.
Feels good to be back on trail again! Not many people out there in the backcountry. Got to Ten Lakes after going up a gruelling pass (9650 ft, I’m very much feeling a whole life lived at basically sea level) and a steep descent. The views from up top are like nothing we’ve ever seen. The mountains on the horizon just get bigger and bigger, massive walls of granite. And in between them, always lurking, the PCT…
Down at the first of the lakes we set up tent at a stellar spot above the lake, ate dinner and filtered water. My water filter doesn’t work anymore apparently; time to write some hate mail in the general Sawyer direction (I’m a pretty consistent back flusher, come on). Not good news, but Turmeric’s filter does work just fine.
The tent spot made up for all the hard hiking today, and a balmy night at 9000 ft awaited. No trace of the freezing temperatures that have been on the forecast.

title: AT 73: Views In Shenandoah
content:
A day with good weather finally. Woke up to the sun shining into the tent.
Got views finally! A little bit of wildlife as well. Easy going with almost dry trail and the well done Shenandoah grading.
Stayed at Rock Spring Hut, which got great views from the secondary hut’s porch. City lights were visible from the shelter as well.

title: AT 13: Wayah Campfire
content:
Another day in NC. They seem to have learned of a marvelous thing called switchbacks, which haven’t been discovered yet in Georgia.
Started the day with Siler Bald and then did the trek over to Wayah Bald. Eery atmosphere with the burnt trees there. Lookout tower is sturdy, the privy there as well, and clean enough to camp in.
Came to Cold Spring Shelter at 17:00, which did feel more like 20:00. Had a nice campfire up on the ridge, good crowd there.
Weather is holding right now, but rain is on the forecast tomorrow.
More pics: Bird, flower, airport from above.

title: AT 107: New York State
content:
Started the day with trail magic and a big climb. Weather is hot and humid, and buggy as well.
Crossed into NY on some nice big boulders. Good landscape here, with more open forest of pines and oaks.
In the evening we went into the Warwick Drive In Movie Theater, which lets hikers tent on their property. Watched the Barbie movie on the bog screen across the tenting area, then went to bed.

title: AT 17: To Fontana Dam
content:
Taped up my ankle and was on my way. Got leftover snacks from dayhikers at Stecoah Gap. Was much needed for the climb out of the gap. Somebody should be held criminally liable for the route up the next hill.
Didn’t feel like quitting early, so pushed on to Fontana Dam. Got some quick grub at the marina, then on to the shelter.
Checked into the Hilton, which had plenty of space left. It’s quite large, has potable water, a shower and stunning views right out of the sleeping bag.
Took of the tape off the ankle and a square inch of skin as well. No tape for me in the near future. Good that antibiotics are OTC here…

title: AT 95: 501 Shelter 1200: Miles
content:
A day with rain showers.
Walked a few miles to the 501 Shelter, one of the more special ones on trail. It is a real building, with bunks, a skylight, running water, electricity, and a caretaker. Took a quick break there; Backfat, Squid, and crew where there as well as Ranger Dan.
Passed the 1200 mile marker. Now just triple digit miles to Katahdin!
Hiked through a controlled burn area, which had been burned half a year earlier. Pretty, and pretty eery too.
Ended the day at Eagles Nest Shelter.

title: AT 67: Banana Pudding
content:
The last full day before resupply/a hostel stay. We did plan big miles for today to get into town early tomorrow.
Being low on food, trail magic by Holy Roller and Tuna at noon came in exceptionally handy. They did go big and got burgers, chips, fruit and then some. The homemade banana pudding was to die for. I even got to pack out some of it in a Talenti jar for tomorrow.
Saw a Copperhead on trail for the first time.
As a afternoon pick me up we got some random Little Debbie products from two dayhikers who we met at a parking area.
Came into camp late, heard some bears rustling around. Had a chill night in one of the nicer shelters out there. With 22.2 miles our longest day yet.

title: AT 169: Ends Beginnings
content:
Got up at 5, packed up a final time. Walked over to Katahdin Stream, and started with the Hunt Trail.
A long and steep trail that is, with really scrambly parts, exposed ridges, big boulders. The views of the mountain itself were incredible, the views of the landscape around it as well.
Reached the summit just before noon, with a crowd of fellow thru hikers already there. Pony, Queso, CBS, Huckfinn, Mudbag, Daybreak, and a few others as well. Lightning and Thunder came in over the Knifes Edge, Daywalker came in on the Hunt as well.
Went down Abol Trail, which took a long time, exposed to the sun, down a big rocky descent. Were greeted at Abol Campground with trail magic, and got a hitch back to Katahdin Stream.
Johnny K picked us up there and gave us a hitch into Millinocket, where we got into the hostel. Had dinner with Meghan and Manuel in the evening, they summited a couple of days before us.
A long journey comes to an end. Thanks for all y’all’s support on and off trail. It has been the most amazing time of my life.

title: AT 18: Zero At The Hilton
content:
Did a resupply run into “town”, which consists of a hotel, the marina, some vacation huts, a gas station, a restaurant, a general store (closed) and a post office (closed). Luckily there’s a shuttle service that you can get around with.
Had a hearty meal at the restaurant; big burger and a lot of sweet tea (now thats a treat!).
Visited the marina once more for more resupply/wifi, then did an extra mile on the AT back to the shelter. Sunset views over the lake were great.
Someone left some Australian goodies in the shelter, which were incorporated into todays dinner.
Foot seems to be healing up slowly.

title: AT 133: Lazy Mornings Late Evenings
content:
Woke up early today, made some hot chocolate on the fireplace, then went into bed again.
Got out of the campground at about 10:00. Shortly after, met Groundhog, who we haven’t seen in a minute. Always nice.
Scenery on trail is getting better and better. Decided late in the evening to go on to the next shelter after arriving at the Lookout one. Bit of night hiking ensued, then got to the Winturri Shelter safe and sound.

title: AT 10: Standing Indian Mountain
content:
Woke up to the sound of rain on the shelter roof. Very cozy. Getting up wasn’t as cozy.
When we headed out, the rain had stopped and all that remained was heavy fog. Not bad hiking weather. At noon the sun did come out, which was a welcome sight
Climbed Standing Indian Mountain, had good views.
Got to Carter Gap Shelter where Tim did appear later on, with a brand new cellphone.
Temperature will get down to freezing tonight, so everybody is sleeping with their water filter and electronics. In the shelter we will be guarded by Truffles the dog.

title: AT 85: Out Of Cross Trails
content:
We’ll have to leave Buckeye Boy for the next few weeks. His foot is not usable yet, so he will stay at the hostel for a while. Sad times.
After saying our farewells we shuttled back to Gathland and hiked on.
Getting really hot and humid right now. Stopped for lunch at one of the state run campsites for shade and water. Met Airquotes again, who did go off trail for July 4th as well.
Set up tent at the Ensign Cowall Shelter after a long day of hiking. Videocalled Buckeye Boy to check if he’s alright (he is), then off to bed.

After saying our farewells we shuttled back to Gathland and hiked on.

Getting really hot and humid right now. Stopped for lunch at one of the state run campsites for shade and water. Met Airquotes again, who did go off trail for July 4th as well.

Set up tent at the Ensign Cowall Shelter after a long day of hiking. Videocalled Buckeye Boy to check if he’s alright (he is), then off to bed.

title: AT 145: Nero At The Barn
content:
Did the five miles to the Pinkham Notch Visitor Center.
Decided to go into town to resupply, hitched the 10 miles into Gorham. After resupplying went for the hostel stay. Did a Walmart visit, the last one on the AT probably. No Walmarts in the Maine part.
Set up tent in the hostel’s backyard for the night.

title: AT 122: Zero At The Zero Day Hostel
content:
The doc told Turmeric to take it easy, so we decided to do a zero day.
The hostel is quite awesome, the company was so as well. Colossus and Rabbit zeroed as well.
In the evening Buckeye turned up as well, and later Maggs and Foxtrot got shuttled in.
Maggs and Buckeye started a fire in the backyard. We tried to do nothing all day and more or less succeeded. Did permethrin oir clothes though.
Another quick creamery run for dinner in the evening.

title: AT 60: Survivors
content:
Survivor wasn’t generally available today, due to his job as a pastor (it’s Sunday). Left us his car keys though, which we used to do a quick trip to IHOP for second breakfast and a Walmart visit.
Came back, didn’t do anything productive all day.
Watched the AT documentary Cocaine Bear before bedtime to remember good times at Blood Mountain.

title: AT 14: Rainy Day To Noc
content:
Started early at 9:00 just when the rain started. The trail soon turned into a stream. Avoiding puddles is a fruitless endeavor. Feet are wet all the time spent hiking.
Climbed the lookout tower on Wesser Bald for spectacular views of nothing.
Big climb down from the ridge up at 5000 ft to the Nantahala Outdoor Center, which is way below 2000 ft. Vegetation in the valley is considerably greener and more lush than up there.
Checked into a cabin at the NOC. Amenities are Very Basic, but it’s warm and dry, so there’s that. Ate dinner at the on site restaurant: Chicken Alfredo Pasta (very yummy), and unlimited soda refills (yay USA).

title: AT 101: Big Day Into Dwg
content:
Turmerics Dad shuttled us and Prepper to the trailhead, then off we went. Leapfrogged a bit with Prepper before we started getting faster and left him a little ways behind.
Turmerics parents and Buckeye Boy met us 7 miles before town and supplied us with water, snacks, and encouragement.
After that pretty long 7 miles into town, where the hostel is right on trail.
Turmerics dad took care of catering and got a lot of takeout stuff, that was just waiting for us. Thanks Dave!
Longest day so far with 23.6 miles and we’re feeling pretty trashed afterwards.

title: AT 46: Rain Pizza
content:
Hiked 19 miles in the rain. Takes amazingly short time if you’re not taking breaks during the day.
The umbrella works really well, was able to not use the rain jacket all day. Which is really big, cause you sweat a lot using rain clothes. Realized that the rain pants are not very useful out here. Might have to look for a rain skirt in town.
Arrived at the Partnership Shelter at 4:30 PM. Shuttled into Marion with Marty and Alex, a thru hiker/support driver (wife) team. Got pizza and snacks, which we brought back to the shelter for dinner.

title: AT 34: Roan High Knob
content:
Started from the apple orchard quite late, then a relaxed day up Roan High Knob. Nice spruce forest and rocks up there again.
Highest shelter on the AT, and fully enclosed with a door. Storm warning for tonight, started raining after we got there. Day hikers came in late carrying beer, wine, cookies, snacks.
Big crowd in here tonight, shelter is packed. Really cozy in there with rain coming down outside.

title: AT 156: Crocker
content:
Woke up early, broke down tent, left the logging road. A hostel stay was calling and we pushed for miles.
Passed South/North Crocker Mountain, who are, despite being 4000ers, fairly unremarkable.
Passed the 2000 mile marker today. That’s a lot of miles. Sub 200 to go!
In the evening we got a really nice sunset, and checked into the Maine Roadhouse.

title: AT 106: Cobmin Ridge Motel Right Wing
content:
Getting and packing up was greatly accelerated by the discovery of a yellow jacket nest in the shelter. Explains why Turmeric got stung yesterday evening.
Made it out of camp by 7:30 trying to beat the heat; the mosquitoes didn’t get the memo of being active just in the afternoon though.
Walked by a big animal sanctuary which was a kind of swampy area. Lots of herons there. Got a little bit of boardwalking in as well, which is always nice.
Did a little break at around 2 PM to cool down, then on to our pickup point. Weather began to turn for the worse in the early evening. Got to a farm shop, where Buckeye Boy got us. Shelters around here are spaced really wonky and wild camping is not allowed, so we went back to the Cobmin Ridge Motel.
More: A lot of turkeys.

title: AT 167: Fall Views
content:
Woke up to a misting, foggy lake. Quite cold and windy.
Sun came out while we were walking, with lake views just incredible. Noon break at a pretty viewpoint above a canyon, then back to walking.
Did the last two hills of the hike, then a late arrival at the last shelter of the wilderness. Did 22 miles again today, with rootier and more uneven terrain than yesterday. The last of the long days; tomorrow a shorter day into Baxter, then after that, the final day.

title: AT 89: New Tent Day
content:
Left the Ironmasters Mansion, went over to the General Store where we didn’t do the Half Gallon Challenge.
Humidity was lower than the last few days, so the going was quite easy, even if the trail got very rocky at times.
Set up the new tent for the first time in the evening. Lets see if this Dyneema/Silpoly combo holds up…

title: AT 138: Mount Moosilauke
content:
Started the day well rested after a night in the Hikers Welcome barn.
Hiked out at 8:15, did a creek crossing, passed the 1800 mile marker, then slow and steady up Mount Moosilauke. First of the White Mountain 4000ers.
Up there spectacular views, clouds, and lunch.
Started the descent just before noon. Took a long time going down some pretty steep sections. Very pretty though.
Came back to the hostel, did a resupply, reorganized food, met up with Toto and Buckeye. Marty, PBJ, Secret Sauce, Foxtrot, Colossus there as well. Good crew.

title: AT 2: Fra Atl
content:
Started early with large crew at the airport. Big thanks to all who did support me.
Status of in flight reading project: Did finish Perdido Street Station 15 minutes before touchdown. Last ~2 hours of flight will be retraced by foot in the next months.
Cleared immigration and touched US soil for the first time. Weather in Atlanta is really nice. Took the MARTA to Dunwoody/Sandy Springs and went shopping: Got a US-charger and Chick-fil-A before getting in bed really early.

title: AT 128: Fresh Mud
content:
Started raining at 6:30 and did so for 2 hours. Waited in the shelter for it to stop, then headed out.
With fresh mud under/all around our feet the day was a long one. Climbed Stratton Mountain just in time to see some bad weather moving in; decided to move on real quick.
Got overtaken by Corndog, who we hadn’t seen in a while. Passed the 3/4 marker. Stayed in the William Douglas Shelter for the night, which we had to our own with together with Maggs.
Pokey shuttled Buckeye to Manchester Center today, where he hiked out of and is ahead of us a bit. Turmeric’s car is at Pokey’s for the rest of the hike now.

title: AT 161: More High Water Reroutes
content:
Did the few miles from Pleasant Pond to Moxie Pond outlet. After deciding that the crossing was not safe at all, we started the long trek around.
After six miles of road walking the feet hurt and energy was low. Moxie Bald had nice views though. Decided to call it a day at the lean to after and get out early tomorrow.
More: Drying out the wet tent on logging roads.

title: AT 103: Cobmin Ridge Left Wing 1:
content:
Another slackpack, this time from hostel to motel. Did an easy day, passing a beaver bog, getting rattled at, and having some nice lake views.
Turmeric’s parents and Buckeye greeted us with trail magic, then we checked into the Cobmin Ridge Motel. Dave scooped out a nice local burger place, where we enjoyed some more lake views.

title: AT 99: More Slackpacking With Prepper
content:
Decided to split the slackpacking bill with Prepper again. Did the fun scramble out of Leheigh Gap early in the morning, then did some more chill miles.
Second of a few nights at the Lookout Hostel, which is pretty nice. Has a really good view from the sitting area. The host/owner Yardsale is pretty cool as well.

title: AT 132: Killington
content:
Got up early and did the 2000 foot climb up Mount Killington.
Went down again, and took an Uber into the town of Killington, where two resupply packages were waiting for us. After organising them and mailing ahead the rest, we got a ride back to the trailhead.
Hiked on a little bit, hit the Maine Junction, where the Appalachian Trail and the Long Trail split.
Stayed the night at Gifford Woods State Park Campground, which is pretty hiker friendly. Got checked in by Ozoner, another thru hiker. Had a hot shower, charged electronics, set up tent.

title: AT 94: What Are We Doing In This Swamp
content:
Broke down camp while the sun came out. Another long day planned.
Had to cross a beaver swamp, which was a little sketchy, but a nice change of scenery. Balancing over half submerged wonky logs does give you a little adrenaline boost. Not really doable without poles. Heard of a guy being in the swamp up to his knees and needing to turn back cause he couldn’t make it through.
Late afternoon I got the last Gatorade from a trail magic guy at the steel bridge, then we went on to William Penn Shelter.

title: AT 118: Three Miles With Buckeye
content:
Today: Big trail magic in a church tent today. Burgers and water for hungry hikers. Buckeye came to meet us as well.
Hiked on to the South Mt Wilcox Shelters, picked up Buckeye on a trailhead three miles before that. He can pretty much keep up with us at this point, which is impressive.
Stayed in the old shelter there, as the new one was pretty full. About everyone here wants to go to the Goose Pond tomorrow, so we’ll have to get out early tomorrow.

title: AT 162: Even More High Water Reroutes
content:
Started the day at 4:15, to have enough time to get to Monson today. Word on the trail is that the upcoming river crossing was up to people necks yesterday. Not a thing to do out here after heavy rain.
Did an unavoidable smaller crossing together with Pony and Queso, which only came up to our hips. Sketchy.
Started a long roadwalk on remote logging roads to get around the Piscataquis River. Ended up walking into Monson on roads instead of the trail. Stopped by the gas station for pizza. Checked out the ATC visitor center, then got into Shaws.
Got a resupply package, bought stuff from the store, got new shoes as well. Hopefully sets us up for the 100 Mile Wilderness coming up.

title: AT 125: Mud Mud Mud Mud Mud Mud
content:
Woke up late to escape the rain, which was supposed to end noonish. The plan worked out, and after a DD breakfast we hit the trail at around noon to just a light sprinkling.
Trail conditions after the rain last night are meh. A lot of mud due to minimal trail maintenance, no functional water bars, very minimal signage.
Lunch at the new Seth Warner Shelter. Shortly after that we took a wrong turn and walked down a literal creek, thinking it was the trail. Double checked after 10 minutes as the ‘trail’ seemed to be too easy to walk on and not muddy enough. Says a lot about the condition of the trail.
Two hours into the day we realized that we misunderestimated the terrain by quite a bit. Mud and trail conditions made us even slower than normal. Decided to just make it to the bailout point of the day. Arrived there with the last of the daylight, with Buckeye, Maggs, and Pokey waiting there for us.
For the night went into Bennington and checked into a motel.
